article ii  license required  conditions no person shall sell purchase barter or deal in junk old metals secondhand articles or antiques and no person shall establish operate or maintain an automobile junkyard within the town without having first obtained a license as provided in this chapter all licenses issued shall be subject to such conditions and restrictions as the town council shall deem appropriate to promote the public health safety or general welfare and shall be revocable at the pleasure of the town council  application application for a license under this chapter shall be made in writing to the town clerk setting forth the name of the applicant the nature and scope of the business proposed and a plan of the property where such business is to be located and conducted including a sketch of the properties of abutting landowners within 200 feet each to be identified by plat and lot number and the names of the owners of the property the town clerk shall establish and publish a deadline for filing a license application pursuant to this chapter a late fee of $2500 shall be imposed for failure to file on or before said deadline    hearing on application by town council the town council shall hold a public hearing on any application for a license under this chapter in any location not lawfully occupied for such purpose at the time of the application for such license notice of such public hearing shall be posted at least seven days but not more than 14 days prior to such hearing in not less than two public places in the town and in a newspaper of general circulation in the town  provided however that before the town council shall post or publish notice of a hearing the applicant shall deposit the sum set out therefor in section 111 with the town clerk plus the cost of posting and publishing such notice such notice shall indicate whether the applicant is either a junk secondhand or antique dealer  prerequisites to issuanceapproval of adjoining the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning snow emergency means when the town administrator or hisher duly authorized agent shall declare that the accumulation of a fall of snow on the public streets and highways of the town is of sufficient quantity as to constitute an emergency affecting the public health safety and welfare of the residents of the town the town administrator or hisher duly authorized agent shall define pursuant to this section the areas of the town in which such snow emergency exists and the duration thereof the town administrator or hisher duly authorized agent shall notify the public that a snow emergency has been declared via media outlets and the towns webpage b restrictions on parking of vehicles the following provisions shall be applicable to al motor vehicles parked on the public streets and highways of the town and the owners operators or persons having charge thereof for such periods of time and in such areas of the town as the town administrator or hisher duly authorized agent shall designate declaring a snow emergency pursuant to subsection a of this section state law reference similar provisions gl 195  3113 1 upon such declaration of a snow emergency by the town administrator or hisher duly authorized agent every owner operator or person having charge of a motor vehicle parked on the public streets and highways of the town in the areas designated by the town administrator shall forthwith remove the vehicle from such public streets and highways and arrange for its storage outside the limits of such public streets and highways during the period of time designated by the town administrator declaring such snow emergency 2 in the areas of the town subject to such snow emergency if any owner operator or person in charge of a motor vehicle parked upon a public street or highway therein is unable refuses or fails to remove such motor vehicle there from any thus removed from the public streets or highways of the town shall not be further removed from the location to which it is towed without the written consent of the owner operator or person having charge thereof or an agent of such owner operator or other person duly authorized in writing in addition to other remedies a person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine away of a motor vehicle parked on the public streets or highways shall call only upon towing service companies which have indicated by a writing deposited with the chief of police agreeing to abide by the provisions of this section respecting such towing charges and other regulations and shall have further agreed to remove motor vehicles for storage if other than upon the premises of or under the direct control of such towing service companies only to the public location as directed by such police officer towing service companies so registered with the chief of police shall be listed in alphabetical order and shall be called upon for their services by such police officers to the greatest possible extent in the order of their appearance on such list violations of this section by any towing service company or by the owner operator or person having charge of a motor vehicle parked upon the public highways of the town during a snow emergency declared by vote of the town council as aforesaid shall upon conviction be punishable by a fine of $500 for each offense and the owner or operator of a towing service company shall be subject upon conviction of a violation of this section to a removal of his name from the approved list of eligible towing service companies 6 nothing contained in this section shall be deemed to prohibit the owner operator or person having charge of a motor vehicle parked upon the public streets or highways of the town during a snow emergency from entering into a private arrangement with a towing service company for the towing and removal of a motor vehicle from such public street or highway to a place of storage without the limits thereof upon such terms and conditions as such person may agree upon  provided however that such towing under private arrangement shall be completed and such vehicle towed away prior to the time a direction by a police officer of the town shall have been issued to have such motor vehicle towed away by an residential parking street only one sticker shall be issued to a resident or owner residential parking street means a street or a portion thereof where 24hour curbside parking is limited to vehicles properly displaying a residential parking permit authorized by this article all other vehicles parking thereon remain subject to parking time restrictions as now and hereafter delineated in the ordinances of the town designated streets will be enumerated in this chapter as amended from time to time    cross reference definitions generally  12 penalties for violation of article a the parking designation is reasonably necessary to achieve the objectives stated as follows 1 reduce high traffic volumes in certain congested residential districts and to encourage the use of public transportation and the use of public and private parking facilities 2 protect certain residential districts from polluted air excessive noise and from litter resulting from the entry parking and egress or traffic in higher than desirable volumes 3 protect the residents of certain residential districts from unreasonable burdens in gaining access to their residences 4 preserve the character of such districts as predominantly residential districts 5 promote traffic flow and the safety of children and other pedestrians in congested residential districts 6 promote the peace comfort convenience and welfare of all town residents and visitors  posting of signs a following the town councils decision to designate a residential parking street parking signs shall be erected thereon b such sign shall inform the vehicle operator that curbside parking on the street is subject to local parking restrictions unless the vehicle displays a residential parking permit or a general visitor or temporary residential parking permit authorized by this article such sign will enumerate all applicable parking restrictions  issuance of permits a any resident or property owner over the age of 16 and a licensed driver may apply for a residential parking permit by completing an application prepared by the town administrator or his designee which shall include the following information 1 name and address of the vehicle owner  2 name and address of the principal operator of the vehicle licensee  3 make model color and registration of the vehicle  and 4 the name of all other licensed drivers within the same residence the drivers license and vehicle registration shall be presented with the application b whenever the town administrator or his designee shall find that the applicant qualifies for a residential parking permit under the provisions of this article he shall issue one resident parking permit in the form of a sticker or some other method prescribed by the town council c the town administrator or his designee may issue one or more temporary residential parking permits for use by a bona fide visitor to a dwelling unit on a residential parking street application for such permits shall be made only by a resident of a dwelling unit on a residential parking street on such form as shall be prescribed by the director of public safety or his designee shall place a reasonable limit on the duration of such temporary permit which time period shall not exceed one week d any business owner may apply for a residential parking permit by completing an application prepared by the town administrator or his designee which shall include the information required in paragraph a above and in addition each business owner shall provide proof of ownership in a business within the town each business owner shall be allowed one permit e all permit applications shall be handled administratively by the town administrator or his designee  provided however that any resident who is refused a residential parking permit by the town administrator may renew their request to the town council for additional consideration in rendering a decision the town council shall give reasonable consideration to the request for a residential permit and the recommendations of the town administrator and the chief of police    renewal or transfer of permits a a holder of a valid permit from the previous year shall be entitled to a new residential parking permit for the current year upon submission of evidence to the director of public safety or his designee that the holder is still qualified for a residential parking permit b the holder of a valid residential parking permit shall receive a new residential parking permit for the purpose of transferring same to another qualifying vehicle upon surrender of the holders existing residential parking permit and completion of a new application c such permits shall be issued on a calendar year basis with new permits available in december of each year  use of permits a a parking permit shall not guarantee or reserve a parking space nor shall it excuse the observance of any traffic or parking regulation b it shall be a violation of this article for the holder of a residential parking permit to use such permit when the permit holder no longer fulfills one or more of the applicable provisions of this article controlling the issuance of permits c it shall be a violation of this article for any person to represent in any fashion that a vehicle is entitled to a parking permit authorized by this article when it is not so entitled the display of a parking permit on a vehicle not entitled to such permit shall constitute a violation of this article d it shall be a violation of this article for any person to duplicate or attempt to duplicate a residential parking permit or to display on any vehicle such a duplicate parking permit  special events any resident on a residential parking street who sponsors a special function or 5161 shall be required to comply with all pertinent provisions of gl 195  5161 et seq reserved editors note i adopted dec 15 199 repealed  179 which pertained to loitering obstructing access to public buildings and prohibited acts and derived from    loitering  prohibited acts  standards for enforcement a definition to loiter means to knowingly remain idle in one general location by either aimlessly walking sitting standing or lying about whether in or out of a motor vehicle b actions prohibited 1 it shall be unlawful for any person to loiter with the intent to commit a crime or other statute or ordinance violation 2 it shall be unlawful for any person to loiter under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or concern that such actions threaten public safety or a breach of the peace as pursuant to subsection d below 3 it shall be unlawful for any person to loiter in a place at a time or in such a manner that impedes or tends to impede the passage of pedestrians or vehicles on a public street or sidewalk under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or concern that such impediments threaten public safety or a breach of the peace pursuant to subsection d below 4 nothing in this section shall be construed to punish conduct which is constitutionally permissible c condition precedent to arrest prior to any arrest or citation hereunder by a law enforcement officer it shall be a requirement that the law enforcement officer shall have previously ordered the person to disperse and remove himself or herself from the area d standards for enforcement in determining whether actions conduct or circumstances warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or concern that the public safety or a breach of the peace is threatened the following factors must be considered by the peace officer 1 the place of the activity or conduct and the usual activities which occur at the location 2 the time of day and duration of the activity or conduct 3 whether the persons purpose is lawful or unlawful 4 whether the activity or conduct creates an unreasonable risk of harm to persons or property 5 whether the activity or conduct is intended to intimidate annoy disturb delay or hinder passersby or persons residing or doing business in the vicinity 6 if on private property whether the property owner tenant or their agent has posted a sign on the property stating no loitering or other statement of similar meaning 7 whether the person to be charged with loitering has been asked by the property owner tenant or their agent or by a security officer to leave the property and whether that person failed to do so immediately and peaceably 8 whether on other occasions the person to be charged with loitering has been asked by the property owner tenant or their agent or by a security officer or law enforcement officer to leave the property and whether or not they failed to do so immediately and peaceably 9 the nature of the activity or conduct complained of and whether it would otherwise be constitutionally protected e penalty for violation  any person found in violation of this section shall be fined up to $50000 andor voluntary community service for not more than 50 hours or any one offense ii 121599     disorderly conduct a a person commits disorderly conduct if he or she intentionally knowingly or recklessly 1 act in an intimidating violent or tumultuous manner toward another or others whereby any person is placed in fear of safety for his or her life limb health or wellbeing  2 act in an intimidating violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby the property of any person is placed in danger of being damaged mutilated defaced or destroyed or is in fact mutilated damaged defaced or destroyed  3 behave in an intimidating violent or forceful manner at any time in upon or in the proximity of a public place in such a manner that such conduct constitutes a clear and present danger to the free and lawful movement of any person or to the extent that any other person will be or is likely to be restrained enjoined incapacitated or stopped in the lawful exercise of his or her business occupation amusement recreation or any other lawful pursuit  4 cause provoke or engage in any fight brawl or tumultuous or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life limb health or wellbeing of another  5 urinate or defecate on any public street alley or sidewalk or the floor of any public place or public building or any place or building where the public has the right to gather or to which it has access or any private property not owned by the party  6 by acts of violence interfere with anothers pursuit of a lawful occupation  7 wilfully knowingly or recklessly make a false alarm or cry of fire or a false request for the assistance of any firefighting apparatus or personnel or wilfully knowingly or recklessly make a false report or request for assistance of any public or conduct a gathering of five or more persons on any private property in a manner which constitutes a substantial disturbance of the quiet enjoyment of private or public property in a significant segment of a neighborhood as a result of conduct constituting a violation of law illustrative of such unlawful conduct is excessive noise or traffic obstruction of public streets by crowds or vehicles illegal parking public drunkenness public urination the service of alcohol to minors fights disturbances of the peace and litter b a gathering constituting a public nuisance may be abated by all reasonable means including but not limited to an order requiring the gathering to be disbanded and citation andor arrest of any law violators under any applicable ordinances and state statutes  notice of unruly gathering  effective periods a when the police department intervenes at a gathering which constitutes a nuisance under this article the premises at which such nuisance occurred shall be furnished with a notice stating that the intervention of the police has been necessitated as a result of a public nuisance under this article caused by an event at the premises the date of the police intervention and that any subsequent event within the period set forth below on the same premises which necessitates police intervention shall result in the joint and several liability of any guests causing the public nuisance or any persons who own or are residents of the property at which the public nuisance occurred or who sponsored the event constituting the public nuisance as more fully set forth below b any notice issued between september 1 and may 31 of any year shall remain in effect until may 31 any notice issued between june 1 and august 31 of any year shall remain in effect until august 31  mailing of notice to property owner and occupants a notice of the intervention shall also be mailed to any property owner on the town of bristol property tax assessment records and the occupants of the premises and shall advise the property owner and the occupants that any subsequent intervention within the effective periods set forth in section 17101b on the same premises shall result in liability of the property owner and of the occupants for all penalties associated with such intervention as more particularly set forth below b additionally notice may be provided to an agent of the owner who controls or regulates the use of the premises if known notice to the owners agent may be provided by hand delivery or by certified or regular mail sent to the agents last known address  persons liable for a subsequent response to a gathering constituting a public nuisance a if the police department is required to respond to a gathering constituting a public nuisance on the premises more than once in any effective period set forth in section 17101b the following persons shall be jointly and severally liable for fines as set forth in section 17104a 1 the person or persons who own the property where the gathering constituting the public nuisance took place provided that notice has been mailed to the owner of the property as set forth herein and the gathering occurs at least two weeks after the mailing of such notice 2 the person or persons residing on or otherwise in control of the property where such gathering took place 3 the person or persons who organized or sponsored such gathering 4 all persons attending such gatherings who engage in any activity resulting in the public nuisance 5 nothing in this section shall be construed to impose liability on the resident or owners of the premises or sponsor of the gathering for the conduct of persons who are present without the express or implied consent of the resident or sponsor as long as the resident and sponsor have taken all steps reasonably necessary to exclude such uninvited participants from the premises including landlords who are actively attempting to evict a tenant from the premises b where a person present with the express or implied consent of the resident or person in charge of the residential unit or the organizer or sponsor engages in conduct which the sponsor or resident or organizer could not reasonably foresee and the conduct is an isolated instance of a person at the event violating the law which the sponsor or resident or organizer is unable to reasonably control without the intervention of the police the unlawful conduct of the individual shall not be attributable to the sponsor or resident or organizer for the purposes of determining whether the event constitutes a public nuisance under this section  penalties for violation a it shall be a punishable by a $50000 fine when intervention at the same location to abate a gathering constituting a public nuisance occurs within any effective period set forth in section 17101b after the property was notified in accordance with section 17101a 1 the violation of this article is punishable by a $50000 fine against each responsible person as set forth in section 17103a14 including each lessee of the property who was present at the gathering 2 the persons who own the property where the unruly gathering took place will be assessed a $50000 fine provided proper notice of a prior violation at the property was provided to the owner pursuant to section 17102 of this article and the gathering occurs at least two weeks after the mailing of such notice b in addition to the above the municipal court shall be authorized to order the person or persons in violation to perform community service for a first intervention ordering community service shall be discretionary for a second or third intervention the municipal court shall in addition to the monetary penalty set forth above order the person or persons in violation to perform not less than 25 hours of community service for a second intervention and not less than 50 hours of community service for a third intervention c in addition to the above the roger williams university dean of students office will be notified of any roger williams university student in violation of an unruly gathering  right to contest notice of unruly gathering a an owner occupant or tenant of the cited premises may contest the issuance of the notice by filing a written petition for review with the town administrator requesting that the town administrator determine whether justification existed for issuing the notice under the provisions of this ordinance the petition must be filed within ten days after the issuance of the notice or if the notice is given by mail within 15 days after the date of the mailing of the notice and not thereafter b the town administrator shall set a time and date for a hearing to be held no later than 30 days after receipt of the written petition and shall notify the petitioner and the solicitors office of the hearing date  parks and recreation footnotes  1  cross reference boats docks and waterways ch 8 this article shall apply to all parks and recreation areas under the jurisdiction of the town unless expressly exempted for the approval of and issuance of facility use permits temporary designations authorizations granting of approvals and other actions the approving governing agency shall be the parks and recreation department      definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in a the name and address of the applicant b the name and address of the persons corporation or association sponsoring the activity if any c the day and hours for which the permit is desired d the park or portion thereof for which the permit is desired e any other information reasonably necessary to a determination as to whether a permit should be issued under this section f variances required from park rules and regulations g standards for issuance of a permit shall include the following findings 1 the proposed activity or use of the park will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the general publics enjoyment of the park 2 the proposed activity and use will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the promotion of public health welfare safety and recreation 3 the proposed activity or uses that are reasonably anticipated will not include violence crime or disorderly conduct 4 the proposed activity will not entail extraordinary or burdensome expense of police operation by the town 5 the facilities desired have not been reserved for other use on the date and hour requested in the application 2 any permit application not filed within the specified time period may be granted or denied at the discretion of the director persons seeking a permit in this manner shall illustrate that it was impossible to file in accordance with subsection b1 of this section and that an emergency exists such applicants waive all rights to appeal as stated in subsection c of this section c appeal within 30 days after the receipt of an application the director shall tell an applicant in writing of its decision to grant or deny a permit in the event of a denial the notification shall include the reason for the denial any aggrieved person shall have the right to appeal to the town council by serving written notice on the town clerk within five working days of the refusal the town council shall decide at its next regularly scheduled meeting after receipt of the appeal by the town clerk the decision of the town council will be final d applicant bound by park rules and applicable ordinances a permittee shall be bound by all park rules and regulations and all applicable members of the general public arising out of such permitted activities in such amounts as may be from time to time determined by the director or hisher designee prior to the commencement of any activity or issuance of any permit f revocation the director or hisher designee shall have the authority to revoke a permit upon a finding of violation of any rule or ordinance or upon good cause
