and employees  261 et seq article i  in general definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning active list means a list of persons who are eligible to be certified to vacancies in a given class of positions allocation of position means the action taken to place a new position in an appropriate class of position and officially assigning to that position the class title for such appropriate class of position appointing authority means the town council having the power by virtue of an ordinance adopted  to make appointments to positions in the town service excepting school personnel and excepting officers and employees who are otherwise provided for under the home rule charter available eligible means any person whose name appears upon a promotional list and who is available for appointment to a given position certification means the act of submitting the required number of available names on an appropriate list to the town administrator for the purpose of making an appointment class specification means a written statement of the duties andor responsibilities characteristic of a class of position and includes the education experience capacity knowledge skill and other qualifications to be required to perform the work of the class position classification plan means an orderly arrangement of positions into separate and distinct classes so that each class will contain those positions which involve similar skills duties and responsibilities classified service means all offices and positions of trust or employment in the town service whether paid or unpaid fulltime or parttime temporary or permanent existing or hereafter created except those placed in the unclassified service by the state merit system act or by subsequent acts demotion means a change of an employee from a position of one class to a position of another class for which a lower maximum rate of pay is provided dismissal means separation of an employee from the town service other than by lay off resignation or retirement lay off means an involuntary separation of an employee from a position in the town service either by reason of reduction of force due to lack of work or lack of funds or by reason of abolishment of the position open competitive examination means an examination which permits persons to compete who meet the requirements of the official announcement and the appropriate class specifications but is not restricted to persons currently employed by the town residence requirements are sometimes waived as provided by law the personnel ordinance of the town pay plan means a schedule of salaries established for the several classes of positions recognized in the classification plan so that all positions of a given class will be paid the same rate or range established for the class position classification means the process of ascertaining analyzing and evaluating the current duties and responsibilities of a position for the purpose of determining its relative place in the classification plan promotional appointment means a competitive examination in which competition is open only to persons who hold a position in the town service and who hold or within three years have held permanent status in the classified service and who meet the requirement of the official announcement and the appropriate class specification promotional list means a list of names of employees arranged in order of their ratings who have been found qualified tests for promotion to positions in higher classes under the provisions of this chapter public hearing means a hearing held after public notice of at least five calendar days at which interested persons may appear and be heard on the matters involved resignation means a separation of an employee from his position in the town service by his own voluntary act or by an unauthorized absence from his position for such a period as is specified in the rules rules means the personnel rules of the town town administrator means the novemberelected town administrator  cross reference definitions generally  12 physical examinations a the appointing authority shall establish a physical examination program which shall require persons employed in positions in the classes he shall designate to be examined by a physician and present certification that they are physically capable of performing the duties required and that their employment in such positions will not be harmful to the town or its employees or other persons b the appointing authority may require such physical examination at the time of appointment and at such other times as may be designated in regulations promulgated for such purpose and shall refuse to approve the appointment of any person who fails to comply with such rule or after appointment shall refuse to certify any payroll bearing the name of any person who fails so to comply  conduct of employees a in accordance with the provisions of this chapter it is the duty of all employees to so conduct themselves inside and outside their offices as to be worthy of the esteem a public employee must enjoy b therefore it shall be the policy of the town that no town employees shall engage in any outside business activities however remote from the function of their office which would in any way interfere with the employees performance of their regular duties or embarrass or bring discredit to the employees or the town town employees who avoid or ignore this policy shall be subject to disciplinary action c furthermore whenever town employees shall so conduct themselves as to cause scandal or to lose or jeopardize such esteem they may be dismissed for the good of the service subject to the provisions of the law and rules  demotions when the services of an employee who holds permanent status are not satisfactory the appointing authority may demote the employee to a position in a lower class and grade and such employee shall be granted permanent status in the class of position to which they have been demoted the compensation in such lower class shall be determined by the provision of section 20116 an employee may be granted a demotion upon request when recommended by their appointing authority such demotion shall be termed a voluntary demotion and shall not be deemed a disciplinary action  resignation a an employee in the classified service desiring to resign in good standing shall give his department head notice of at least 14 calendar days prior to termination of services such resignation shall be submitted on the appropriate forms signed by the employee b any employee who is absent from duty without authorized leave for five consecutive working days or who fails to resume his duties at the expiration of a leave of absence shall be deemed to have resigned without notice such resignation shall be submitted on the appropriate form signed by the appointing authority and must be approved by the personnel board to become effective such resignation shall be not in good standing unless otherwise requested by the appointing authority and approved by the personnel board in each instance of such resignation without notice a copy of such action shall be mailed by the appointing authority to the last known address of the employee within five days after the approval of the personnel board  union agreements nothing in this chapter is to be interpreted as altering agreements reached between the town and the recognized union and association representatives relative to prescribed procedures of appeal and arbitration of grievances  conflicts of interest a any violation of section 1310 of the charter is determined to be a conflict of interest violation b any resident of the town or other interested citizen may instigate an inquiry into a possible conflict of interest violation an investigation may be instigated by presenting a written statement of an alleged violation to the town administrator town solicitor or any member of the town council who after determining that there may be merit to the complaint may present the same to the town council for appropriate action c the town council is empowered to conduct conflict of interest hearings upon receipt of a statement of alleged violation the council may proceed to a conflict of interest hearing or may conduct its own investigation in order to determine whether or not a hearing should be held d the party charged with conflict of interest shall be entitled to notice the notice shall be in writing shall be definite and certain and must contain sufficient specifications in order to adequately inform the party charged so as to enable him to prepare an explanation or a defense the notice may be personally served by any person eligible to serve subpoenas or may be mailed to the party charged the notice shall allow the party charged reasonable time before the hearing date to prepare his explanation or defense the party charged may waive notice and proceed to the hearing e the party charged shall have the right to counsel he shall have the right to subpoena witnesses or otherwise meet the charges with other competent evidence he shall have the right to crossexamine all witnesses he shall have the right to present oral argument f all witnesses will be sworn and their testimony given under oath g the hearing shall be generally informal in that there will be no strict procedural rules the technical rules of evidence will be suspended to the extent that no frivolous or irrelevant matters will be permitted in the event of any dispute over procedure or evidence a vote of the town council shall be binding h the decision of the town council shall be based on competent and substantial evidence and by a fair preponderance of the evidence  registration of municipal employees and town officials a engagement of office every person appointed to office and every employee of the town shall before he shall act therein and before he shall be compensated therefor have his name and address filed with the town clerk b filing filing shall be a communication of the appointing or employing authority to the town clerk such filing shall be a permanent record and a public record c reports of changes in status of employees every appointment transfer promotion dismissal vacancy change of salary rate except acrosstheboard changes or changes made by budget appropriation leave of absence absence from duty and other service of the town shall be reported and filed with the town clerk  secs 2092040  reserved article ii  classification and pay plan classification plan a the classification plan shall consist of the approved class specifications adopted for each class of position in the town classified service class specifications are intended to be descriptive and explanatory and are not necessarily inclusive or exclusive b in determining the class of position to which any position should be allocated or reallocated the specification of each class shall be read as a whole consideration shall be given to the general and specific duties responsibilities qualifications required for appointment and relationship to other classes as together affording a description of the kind of employment that the class is intended to embrace or include the use of a particular expression or illustration as to the duties andor responsibilities shall not be held to exclude others not mentioned that are substantially similar as to kind and level of difficulty and responsibility c whenever new positions are authorized and created whenever the duties and responsibilities of existing positions change or whenever the classification plan is amended the positions shall be reviewed in cooperation with the appointing authority d when a class specification is revised the incumbents of positions in the class shall be employed in the revised class with the same status held prior to the revision and if the pay range is changed in a concurrent action the appropriate rate or step in the new range shall apply  pay plan for the convenience of all concerned the regulations affecting the administration of the pay plan have been included in the appropriate sections of this chapter  secs 20432075  reserved article iii  examinations notice a announcement the town administrator shall prepare official announcements for open competitive and promotional examinations which shall include the following information 1 the title salary range and a brief statement of the duties to be performed in the class to be examined 2 the opening and closing date of the application period and places where applications may be obtained 3 the relative weights assigned to the various phases of the examination 4 the minimum required final earned rating 5 the requirements as to residence and citizenship b publication the official announcement of all examinations shall be posted in the town hall published in at least one weekly newspaper published in the state and may be forwarded for publication to other daily newspapers published in the state  application a all applications for examinations shall be made on forms prescribed by the town administrator and shall constitute an integral part of every examination on such forms the town administrator may require information as to the education training and experience of the applicant and such other information as he may deem pertinent the town administrator may require any applicant for any examination to submit documented proof of the possession of any license certificate degree or other qualification claimed or required by law or these rules and may refuse credit for such claimed or required qualification in the absence of such proof b claims made by applicants relative to citizenship residence preference as a war veteran or disabled war veteran age education experience or other evidence of eligibility or qualification shall be subject to verification by authentic proof thereof under such regulations as the town administrator may prescribe and credit for such claims may be denied in the absence of such proof c no application may be accepted after the close of the announced filing period except that the town administrator may order the acceptance of any application or information supplementary thereto received after the close of such period and at least seven calendar days prior to the administration of the first phase of the examination this period shall be called the grace period  disqualification of applicants a the town administrator may deny admission to examination to any applicant if the information contained in such application conclusively shows that the applicant has failed to present evidence that he possesses sufficient qualifications to warrant examination as set forth in the specifications for the class of positions b information as to education and experience as submitted in such application and subject to verification as provided in section 2077 shall be the major factor upon which the town administrator may reject or accept the application of any applicant for admission to examination c after an application has been filed and the grace period has ended no supplementary statement explanation or additional claim of qualification may be accepted or considered in any appeal from denial of admission to the examination or from any examination ratings except that the town administrator may request from the applicant or any other source such information as he deems necessary to clarify or verify statements on claims appearing in the original application and may accept all of such information or such part as he deems appropriate as part of the original application nothing in this section shall be interpreted however to require the town administrator to request such information nor shall his failure to do so constitute a grievance in any instance d the town administrator may reject the application of any person for admission to an examination may refuse to examine an applicant  or after examination may remove his name from the employment list or may refuse to certify for appointment  or following certification may withdraw the certification of any eligible 1 who is physically or mentally so disabled as to be incapable of proper performance of the required duties  2 who is addicted to the use of narcotics or excessive use of intoxicating liquors  3 who has been found guilty of any infamous or notoriously disgraceful conduct  4 who has been dismissed from the state service for delinquency misconduct or other similar cause  5 who has made false statement of material fact in his application  6 whose conduct during an examination is deemed to be improper  or 7 who has otherwise violated this chapter e any person who feels aggrieved by a decision of the town administrator under this section may appeal to the personnel board  conduct a policy statement appointing authorities or their duly authorized representatives shall be granted at their request the privilege of reviewing proposed examination material to ensure a proper relationship between the examination and the positions to be covered by the resulting lists except when such examinations are standardized printed examinations mailed sealed from authorized agencies b the personnel board shall make all reasonable effort to preserve the anonymity of candidates the use of identification numbers instead of names on all test papers shall be required c when an employment or promotional list is established each candidate shall be notified by mail of his relative position on the employment or promotional list or his failure to attain a place on such list d if the personnel board is of the opinion that the conditions under which any examination was held were not such as to be fair to the candidates it may order that the completed examination or any part thereof be cancelled and that a new examination be held e whenever two or more competitors have qualified earned ratings their names shall be arranged on employment or promotional lists in the order of their performances in the written tests  provided however that when such arrangement fails to resolve a tie the order on the lists shall be the same as the order in which their applications were timestamped or by seniority within the town service where practical determination by seniority shall have preference f a manifest error in any examination if called to the attention of the personnel board within ten calendar days after the establishment of a list resulting from such examination shall be corrected by it persons affected by such correction shall be notified by mail  review any examinee or his authorized representative shall be permitted to review the test papers of such examinee and the score assigned thereto under the following conditions 1 all phases of the examination must have been completed and the lists established therefrom 2 written request for such review must be made to the personnel board by the examinee or his authorized representative within five calendar days after the mailing of the official notice of examination results of the examination to him by the personnel board or town administrator 3 such review shall be permitted only in the office of the town administrator during business hours in the presence of a person designated by the town administrator to assist in the review and to safeguard official records from addition deletion or other alteration  appeal from results a within five calendar days after the review of an examination as provided for in section 2080 or within ten calendar days after the mailing of the results of the examination to the examinee by the personnel board whichever date is later an examinee who considers himself aggrieved by such results may file with the personnel board an appeal from the score assigned him in such examination and be heard at reasonable length thereon such appeal shall be in writing and shall include a detailed statement of the items of the examination to which exception is taken by such examinee the personnel board shall render its decision within five days after the conclusion of such hearing b any changes in lists resulting from the procedures outlined in subsection a of this section or following sections shall not invalidate any certification or appointment previously made from such lists  promotional examination a eligibility requirements promotional examinations shall be conducted in the same manner as open competitive examinations subject to the following conditions a person is eligible for promotional examination if he satisfies all the following requirements on the closing date for filing applications in the official announcement of the examination 1 he must hold a position in the town service 2 he must meet the minimum requirements established for the examination 3 he must hold or within three years have held permanent status in the town service 4 his service ratings must be considered b basis whenever the personnel board shall deem the best interests of the town to be served thereby it may conduct promotional examinations on a divisional or departmental basis in which case admission to such examinations shall be restricted to candidates who meet the requirements of subsection a of this section and whose employment requirements shall be met in the departments designated in the announcement c promotion to chief of police promotions to chief of police shall be made upon the following basis 1 in order to be eligible for promotion to the grade of chief of police the candidate for promotion shall be a police officer with at least three years experience above the rank of patrol officer in any organized police department 2 applicants must take a written examination furnished by a testing concern outside the state such examination shall be obtained by conducted by and scored by the personnel board of the town points for the written examination will be apportioned so that out of the total possible score no more than 60 points may be obtained on a written examination 3 each applicant shall be evaluated by the director of public safety these evaluations shall be submitted to the personnel board prior to the conduct of the written examination and must be in the form of a numerical quantity not to exceed a value of 30 points 4 points shall be awarded on the basis of experience in any organized police department at the rate of two points for each year of experience and counted toward the total score of the applicant however in no event shall experience credits be accumulated to more than ten points 5 the personnel board shall total the points from the written examination evaluation and experience to compute the final grading and certify the names and scores of applicants the personnel board shall prepare a listing of applicants names and scores and provide this list to the director of public safety who shall select for promotion from the three applicants receiving the highest scores promotion of the applicant shall be made by the director of public safety within 30 days of the certification of scores examination of scores and standing of each applicant shall be provided to the applicant requesting his score but scores and standing shall not be open to the general public 6 the personnel board shall maintain the list of applicants names and scores for a period not to exceed one year from the date on which it was originally established  at the expiration of the year a new examination must be given and a new certified list established for future promotions d promotion to fire chief promotions to fire chief shall be made upon the following basis 1 qualifications in order to be eligible for promotion to the grade of fire chief the candidate shall a be a member of the town fire department  and b have at least three years active experience in the field of firefighting and fire prevention 2 application scoring system upon meeting the threshold qualifications listed in subsection 1 above an applicant shall then be evaluated on the basis of a 100point scale with the availability of points as follows written examination 60 points experience 20 points interview with the town administrator 20 points a examination applicant must take a written examination furnished by a testing concern outside the state such examination shall be obtained by conducted by and scored by the personnel board of the town points for the written examination will be apportioned so that out of the total possible score no more than 60 points may be obtained on a written examination b experience points shall be awarded on the basis of experience in the town fire department at the rate of two points for each year of experience and counted toward the total score of the applicant no more than 20 points may be awarded on the basis of experience c interview each applicant shall be evaluated by the town administrator and these evaluations shall then be submitted to the personnel board no more than 20 points may be awarded on the basis of performance in the interview 3 final selection the personnel board shall total the points from the written examination evaluation and experience to compute the final grading and certify the names and scores of the applicants the personnel board shall prepare a listing of applicants names and scores and provide this list to the town administrator the town administrator shall interview the applicants receiving the three highest scores a second time from this group the town administrator shall select a new fire chief promotion of the applicant shall be made by the town administrator within 30 days of the certification of scores examination of scores and standing of each applicant shall be provided to the applicant requesting hisher score but scores and standing shall not be open to the general public 4 the personnel board shall maintain the list of applicants names and scores for a period not to exceed one year from the date on which it was originally established  at the expiration of the year a new examination must be given and a new certified list established for future promotions e promotions to sergeant promotions to sergeant shall be made upon the following basis 1 in order to be eligible for promotion to the grade of sergeant the applicant must have five years of continuous service as a patrol officer including his probationary period promotions to office in ranks above the rank of sergeant shall be open to all officers in the grade next below the grade in which the vacancy exists with the exception to the chief of police 2 applicants must be high school graduates or possess a high school equivalency certificate before becoming eligible for promotion to sergeant 3 applicants must take a written examination furnished by a testing concern outside the state such examination shall be obtained conducted and scored by the personnel board of the town the points for the written examination will be apportioned so that out of the total possible score no more than 60 points may be obtained on a written examination 4 applicants shall be evaluated by the chief of police of the town police department and the points for this evaluation shall be apportioned so that no more than 15 points of the total possible score may be obtained 5 points shall be awarded on the basis of seniority in the town police department on a basis of two points for each year in the department and counted toward the total scores of the applicant however in no event shall seniority credits be accumulated to more than 15 points 6 the personnel board shall total the points from the written examination evaluation and seniority to compute the final grading and certify the names and scores of the applicants to the town administratordirector of public safety who shall select for promotion from the three officers receiving the highest score promotion of the officer shall be made by the town administratordirector of public safety within 30 days of the certification of scores examination of scores and standings of each candidate shall be provided to the candidate requesting his score        compliance with federal standards the following provisions are adopted to provide for compliance with the federal standards for a merit system of personnel administration by those agencies receiving grantsinaid under federal statutes which require application of personnel standards on a merit basis to the maximum extent possible lists of eligibles established competition will be maintained for those classes where vacancies can be anticipated since it may not be possible to fill all vacancies from such lists the appointing authority will determine as of june 30 and december 31 each year the classes in which temporary employees are serving in the federally grantaided agencies subject to the federal merit system standards he will conduct an examination during the sixmonth period following this determination for each such class for which an examination had not been held during the sixmonth period preceding the date the determination was made  secs 208420115  reserved article iv  certification procedures a prior to the establishment of a list of eligibles for a class of position or when such a list is established the appointing authority shall request each candidate or eligible to notify him within five calendar days of the date of the mailing of notice to him whether or not he is available for certification to any vacant position in the class of position when such notice of availability is returned to the appointing authority the decision of the eligible shall be recorded  and certification of those available shall proceed according to law when in the process of certification an available eligible is properly reached on such list the appointing authority shall notify such eligible that he has been certified to an appointing authority for an interview relative to appointment to a position in the class of position for which the list was established or deemed appropriate it shall be the responsibility of each such eligible when so notified to contact the appointing authority for an interview relative to appointment b in the event of failure on the part of the eligible to return such notice of availability to the appointing authority within the time allowed he shall be deemed unavailable for such certification and his name shall be placed on the inactive list until such time as he properly establishes his availability for such position if an available eligible fails to report to an appointing authority for an interview within five calendar days from the date of notice of certification was mailed to him at his last known address by the appointing authority he shall be deemed to have refused such certification and the appointing authority may order his name placed on the inactive list for such position c if an eligible who has been certified accepts an appointment and thereafter fails to present himself for duty on the date he is instructed to do so he shall be deemed to have refused appointment and his name shall be placed on the inactive list for such position d it shall be the duty of the appointing authority to accord to each eligible certified to him the opportunity of an interview relative to appointment and no appointment shall be effective unless such opportunity has been so accorded each certified eligible e the appointing authority requesting certification of a list of eligibles shall make an appointment within ten calendar days from the date such list is mailed to him by the personnel board f all appointments to positions in the town service shall be made at the minimum salary applicable to the class with the following exceptions 1 upon recommendation of the appointing authority appointments of employees who leave one class of position to accept appointment in another may be made at the existing salary of such employees  provided however that no appointment shall be made at any salary higher than the maximum of the range except that the provisions of this chapter shall apply to longevity increases when under the provisions of this section an existing salary falls between two successive steps of the new salary range the appointment shall be made at the higher step however upon recommendation of the appointing authority concerned an employee who leaves one class of position to accept appointment in another class of positions which is in a higher pay range may be appointed at that pay rate within the established range for the new class which is next above his present rate of pay or the minimum of the new class whichever is the greater  when under the provisions of this section the employees existing salary falls between two successive pay rates of the new range the appointment shall be made at the higher pay rate  plus one additional pay rate  provided however that no appointment shall be made at any salary higher than the maximum of the range except that the provisions of this chapter shall apply to longevity increases 2 when an employee is required to work in a higher class of position for a period of 11 consecutive days or more such employees shall receive the lowest salary rate of that higher class which will provide a pay increase of at least one step over his present base rate retroactive to the first day of such assignment  rules and procedures for personnel board hearings a notification and time an employee whose petition is accepted may be granted a meeting with the personnel board the employee shall be notified by mail as to the time and place by authority of a majority of members of the personnel board during the regular meeting at which time the petition is taken the time and place of the hearing shall be mutually convenient to all parties including the personnel board b right to be heard the petitioning employee or his legal advisor at the onset of the meeting must first establish that he is a permanent employee covered by the personnel system of the town in accordance with the charter of the town the classification system and such personnel rules as established by the personnel board c type of hearing once the petitioning employee has established his right to be heard he may then decide whether the hearing shall be open to the public d the hearing the hearing shall be conducted as follows 1 the hearing shall be conducted by the personnel board a quorum shall consist of at least three board members and a majority of the members present may determine any matter legally before them any board member who did not hear all of the evidence shall not vote on the final deliberations of the board 2 each personnel board member may question the petitioning employee or witness thereof at any length 3 the personnel board can insist upon seeing documentary evidence to back up any allegations by the petitioning employee or by any witness this may include but not be limited to warrant of appointment town employee records payroll records and the like 4 in accordance with the charter article twelve section 120 investigations during the course of any investigation or hearing the personnel board may request any employee of the town to attend and give witness any employee refusing to do so may be subject to disciplinary action as provided in section 1205 5 the employee and all witnesses will be heard under oath all witnesses can be sworn by the chairperson pro tem of the board or by any other person eligible to administer oaths 6 all parties shall have the right to counsel  the right to present witnesses or other competent evidence  the right to cross examine witnesses  and to present oral argument 7 a court stenographer shall be hired to record the proceedings 8 the hearing shall be generally informal in that there will be no strict procedural rules and also the technical rules of evidence will be suspended to the extent that no frivolous or irrelevant matters will be permitted 9 in the event of any dispute concerning the hearing of the application of this chapter a vote of the board shall be binding 10 to ensure the completeness of any investigation evidence may be gathered after a recess and continued until the court is satisfied at having received all evidence when the hearings are over the personnel board shall meet in closed session to render a decision the employee shall be notified of the decision by mail within three days  secs 2011820125  reserved article v  post retirement benefits fund establishment of post retirement benefits fund a there shall be established a fund separate and apart from the general revenues of the town known as post retirement benefits fund b the post retirement benefits fund is hereby established to provide the town with a fund into which funds shall be deposited from time to time but at least annually to provide funds to pay the towns liability for payment of insurance premiums in connection with medical and other benefits for its employees after retirement which includes but is not limited to medical dental vision life insurance disability insurance and other benefits whether optional or mandatory in effect now or to be in effect in the future at the time of retirement c the post retirement benefits fund shall be administered by a board of trustees as hereinafter provided such post retirement benefits fund shall consist of 1 all monies and securities deposited therein by the treasurer designated to be deposited therein by the town administrator upon the recommendation of the treasurer subject to town council approval 2 all interest dividends and other income derived from the above d the town will pay into the post retirement benefits fund the percentage designated by the trustees of the total sum needed to provide the benefits as set forth in this article such sum is based on the certified actuarial report as prepared by an independent actuarial firm  board of trustees a the board of trustees of the post retirement benefits fund shall consist of five members  one of whom shall be appointed by the town administrator  three of whom shall be appointed by the town council  and the treasurerfinance director then in office or his or her designee b all appointees shall be financially literate and at least two of the three town council appointees shall have educational training experience or strong working backgrounds in investment management pension accounting or finance or otherwise demonstrate an ability to understand and faithfully execute the duties of the board of trustees residence in the town is preferable but not mandatory c members appointed by the town council and the town administrator shall serve for threeyear staggered terms of the initial members appointed under this section one member shall be designated to serve a oneyear term two shall be designated to serve a twoyear term and one shall be designated to serve a threeyear term no member shall serve more than three consecutive terms d a member will continue as a trustee until the earliest of 1 hisher removal or replacement by the town council or town administrator or in the case of the town treasurer when heshe ceases to be the incumbent of that office  2 hisher resignation in writing is delivered to the town council or town administrator  3 hisher death disability or incapacity to serve  4 expiration of hisher term  5 hisher conviction of a felony or crime of moral turpitude  6 upon hisher absence from two consecutive regular meetings without the consent of the chairperson e if at any time there shall be a vacancy in the membership of the trustees the remaining trustees shall not act until such vacancy is filled by action of the town council or town administrator or the swearingin of a succeeding or temporary town treasurer the compensation if any and expenses incurred by the trustees in the fulfillment of their duties hereunder shall be paid by the town from the assets of the post retirement benefits fund f the trustees shall meet at least once in each fiscal year and more frequently as requested by a majority of the trustees as may be required an agenda of each meeting shall be prepared by the town treasurer and circulated to each trustee prior to the meeting date and posted in accordance with the open meeting law statute    responsibilities the trustees shall be responsible for the general administration investment and maintenance of the post retirement benefits fund and for the payment of insurance premiums from it in amounts sufficient to satisfy the towns obligation for post retirement medical benefits the trustees may from time to time adopt bylaws rules and regulations for its administration and for the conduct and transaction of their business affairs as trustees they shall have such power as may be necessary to discharge their duties including but not limited to the power to interpret and construe the provisions hereof determine all questions of date of retirement eligibility duration of service continuity of service dates of birth participation or retirement and similar related matters subject to existing contract provisions and their determination of all questions shall be binding upon all participants or any others concerned subject to existing contract provisions all matters falling outside of the scope of the powers and duties of the trustees and not otherwise provided for herein shall be referred to the town council which shall have the power to act thereon  fiscal powers a the board of trustees shall have with respect to all monies and properties of the post retirement benefits fund at any time held by them power in their discretion to invest and reinvest in any personal property including but not by way of limitation common or preferred stocks bonds certificates of deposit interest or participation mutual funds and other forms of security or investment without being limited in any respect by statute or court rule or decision of any jurisdiction now or hereafter in force purporting to limit or otherwise affect investments by trustees and without regard to the proportion such property or properties of a similar character so held or thereafter acquired may bear to the entire amount of the post retirement benefits fund and to make such payment from such post retirement benefits fund as herein provided b the board of trustees shall have power and authority in their discretion to have a bank or trust company which is licensed in the state or any other financial institution to serve as their agent in keeping custody of the monies and securities in such fund in keeping accounts and for other duties in connection with the administration of the post retirement benefits fund  and they are further authorized in their discretion to employ such bank or trust company or financial institution as agent in the investment of the post retirement benefits fund and otherwise to assist in its management and to pay for any of such foregoing services there shall be no liability on the part of the trustees in the management of the post retirement benefits fund by such an agent selected by them in good faith  consultants the trustees shall have the power in their discretion to employ one or more consultants actuaries accountants attorneys or other professionals at such times as are necessary or advisable to assure the maintenance of the post retirement benefits fund on a sound actuarial basis which professionals shall make periodic actuarial computations for the purposes thereof and to assist with the administration of the post retirement benefits fund the expenses of the consultants will be payable from the post retirement benefits fund unless otherwise authorized by the town council  liability a the trustees shall use ordinary care and reasonable diligence in the performance of their duty and no trustee shall be personally liable for any error of omission or commission unless such error results from his or her own gross negligence willful misconduct or lack of good faith  nor shall any trustee be personally liable for any act of any other trustee or trustees  fund assets not subject to sale encumbrance etc no part of the post retirement benefits fund assets shall be subject in any manner to sale transfer alienation pledge assignment attachment or any other encumbrance whether voluntary or involuntary by operation of law or court order any attempt to sell transfer alienate pledge assign or otherwise encumber the assets of the post retirement benefits fund shall be void and of no force and effect  mistakes resulting in incorrect payments to the extent a distribution has been made from the post retirement benefits fund that a was based on incorrect or inaccurate information received by trustees at the time or b resulted in an overpayment the trustees shall use their best efforts to apply such overpayment to the next succeeding payment due or otherwise receive a credit or deposit any refund received into the post retirement benefits fund to the extent of such overpayment  obligation of employees to contribute to post retirement benefits fund on or after  each employee of the town shall be required to contribute to the post retirement benefits fund as a condition to such employees continued employment with the town and right to receive the medical benefits from the town after such employees retirement for which the post retirement benefits fund was established a percentage of the insurance premium to be paid by the town in connection with the medical and other benefits to be provided employees after retirement based upon a percentage of such employees wages such amount if not otherwise determined by an applicable collective bargaining agreement or employment contract shall equal up to onehalf of the actuarially deferred cost of such post retirement benefit otherwise such contribution shall be equal to the copay provisions established in accordance with existing collective bargaining agreements or employment contracts in effect  distributions from the post retirement benefits fund at any time but not more frequently than monthly the treasurer shall submit a statement or invoice for premiums due during such fiscal period for medical benefits due retired employees of the town which statement shall include the amount to be paid from the post retirement benefits fund the trustees shall make arrangements to withdraw from the post retirement benefits fund an amount sufficient to pay such premiums due and forward such funds to the treasurer no later than ten days prior to the premium due dates  police footnotes  1  charter reference police department  801 cross reference administration ch 2  officers and employees  261 et seq  alarm systems ch 4  motor vehicles and traffic ch 16  offenses and miscellaneous provisions ch 17 article i  in general composition of police force the permanent police force of the town shall consist of one chief of police and such officers and other members as may be deemed necessary and expedient by the town council as recommended by the town administrator for the protection of the inhabitants of the town the property therein and all other matters relating to police work  powers and duties of officerschief of police a the chief of police shall be at the head of the police department and shall have precedence and entire control of the police department and its members when engaged in the service of the town b the chief of police shall lay out and arrange the beats or routes over which the police are to travel the chief of police shall also designate the hours or time of each officers duty during the nighttime and during the daytime at the station or on beats or routes the chief of police is authorized to make distribution of all special police duty among the members of the permanent police force c the chief of police shall have his headquarters and be on duty at such place within the town that the town administrator may from time to time by order designate and shall make such transfers of the members of the police force as he may from time to time by order direct he shall devote his entire time to the affairs of the town to preserve the peace order and cleanliness thereof and to this end shall execute and enforce all laws of the state relating to the town and he shall cause proceedings to be instituted for the prosecution of violations of the laws and ordinances and attend to the trial of the same d the chief of police shall promptly report all cases of absence neglect of duty or other infringements or violations of this any other town ordinances rules and regulations of the police and violations of state laws to the town administrator and he shall keep the town administrator informed of all matters relating to the police or interests of the town the chief of police and other members of the police department shall use their best efforts to bring offenders to lawful punishment e the chief of police shall keep or cause to be kept a full and complete record of all the business of the police department and he shall make special reports to the town administrator whenever required or requested by him to do so annually he shall present to the town council a complete report of all of the work performed by the police department during the previous fiscal year of the town he shall also include in his report such recommendations as he shall deem advisable to promote the efficiency of the police department f the chief of police shall present to the town administrator as required a complete report of all of the work performed by the police department during the previous month with any recommendations that he deems advisable to promote the efficiency of the police department  samecaptain of police the captain of police when in charge of the police force shall ascertain by personal investigation the presence of each officer under him at his proper place of duty he shall acquaint himself thoroughly with the beats of the officers on duty during such time and he shall be certain that the whole of such beats are properly covered at all times by the police officers and police constables he shall promptly report to the chief of police any officer absent from his beat neglect of discipline neglect of duty or for disobedience of orders and failure to do so shall be deemed sufficient cause for suspension or discharge from the permanent police force  samesergeants the sergeants of police under the direction of the chief of police or the captain of police in charge shall carry out the orders of the chief of police or the captain of police as the case may be in direct supervision of the police constables in covering the various beats in the town and shall report all their doings and the performance of the duties of the police constables directly to the chief of police or the captain of police in the absence of the chief of police  duties of police officers generally a all members of the police force shall devote their entire time to the preservation of the peace and order of the town and discharge such other duties either by day or by night as by special orders they may be required to perform or as required of them by state laws this any other ordinances of the town and the rules and regulations of the police department b the members of the permanent police force shall possess intimate knowledge of such laws of the state this any other ordinances of the town as shall appertain to their performance of police duty c each police officer of the town whether he is an officer or a patrol officer is required by his oath of office and by this chapter to thoroughly understand and realize that he is fully liable individually as far as his ability will allow him for the preservation of peace and good order in the town and for the enforcement of the laws of the state and the town not inconsistent with his duty as a police officer d each police officer shall report at police headquarters at such times as the chief of police shall designate  and if absent except by permission of the chief of police deduction shall be made from his pay after reporting for duty and receiving orders and communications each officer shall report to the beat route or duty assigned to him he shall not leave his beat route or duty unless relieved by order of the chief of police except in case of fire arrest of a prisoner or other necessary absence or duty whenever occasion requires police officers are liable to be called into service for any portion of the day or night with such additional pay as the town council may determine e each police officer shall note all street or sidewalk obstructions or defects therein liable to cause accidents removing the same whenever practicable  all streetlamps not lighted  all places where noisome dangerous or illegal trade is carried on  and all nuisances and other matters relating to the safety and convenience of the public or to the interests of the town and shall promptly report the same to the chief of police he shall examine all gates doors and windows of dwellings and stores to see that they are properly secured and if not secured shall notify the inmates if any and if none shall make the same secure and notify the owners as soon as possible he shall watch vacant houses  be diligent to prevent fire  observe all places where waste material of a combustible nature has been allowed to accumulate reporting the same to the chief of police upon retiring from his beat at the close of that days duty  and also notify the chief of police of all ashes garbage dead animals and other nuisances thrown into the streets f each police officer shall instantly report to the scene of any disturbance on his beat and use his best endeavors to restore order taking into custody any person that has committed a felonious assault or other crime or misdemeanor and conveying them at once to the jail to await the order of the officer in charge and thereafter promptly return to his beat  police and special constablessupervision all police constables who are not appointed officers or patrol officers of the permanent police force of the town and all special constables without power to serve civil process when employed in the service of the town in the execution of the laws of the state the ordinances of the town and the orders of the town council shall except as may be otherwise provided by the statutes of the state be subject to and under the control and direction of the chief of police in the manner to the extent and with the limitations governing the permanent police force of the town  sameservice at places of public entertainment and resort a all persons who desire the attendance and services of police at places of public entertainment and resort shall except as may be otherwise provided by the statutes of the state make application thereof to the chief of police upon the receipt of such application the chief of police shall designate and assign from the police and special constables who are not members of the permanent police force of the town the required number of persons for such service  provided however that this shall not prevent when necessary or desirable the assignment of a member of the permanent police force for attendance upon and service at any place of public entertainment or resort b the town administrator shall from time to time fix and determine the amount of compensation to be paid to the police and special constables assigned for service under this section c all persons who receive the services of the police at places of public entertainment and resort shall be liable for and shall pay to the police officers and police constables who perform this duty such compensation as may be fixed and determined by the town council for such services  improper political activity of police officers no member of the police force shall actively advocate or in any way actively assist in or attempt to defeat the election of any officer or group of officers or candidate or group of candidates for office in the town but this section shall not be construed to prevent the casting of their ballots at caucuses or elections by such members any violation of this section will be deemed sufficient cause for the removal from office of the member guilty thereof  compensation a the officers and members of the police force shall receive such compensation payable as the town council may from time to time determine b the pay of all members of the police force shall be in full compensation for all services  and all fees fines and penalties in any case in which the town or state is a party including commitment and witness fees to which any member of the force may be entitled shall be paid into the treasury of the town and shall be used for the reduction of the town debt  disciplinary action against police officers a any member of the permanent police force may be punished in accordance with the police officers bill of rights either by reprimand forfeiture of pay or by dismissal from the force on conviction of including but not limited to any one of the following offenses 1 intoxication 2 an act of insubordination or disrespect towards a superior officer 3 neglect of duty 4 violation of rules 5 neglect or disobedience of orders 6 any legal offense of a criminal nature 7 absence without leave 8 immoral conduct 9 conduct unbecoming an officer 10 incapacity mental or physical 11 any breach of discipline 12 actively advocating or assisting in defeating candidates for public office 13 communicating information relating to police work without permission of the chief of police 14 not patrolling or not properly patrolling his beat or route during his tour of patrol duty 15 failing to report a crime committed on his beat or route during his tour of patrol duty 16 unnecessary absence from his beat or route during his tour of patrol duty b charges preferred against any member of the police force shall be in writing verified by oath of the complainant any member of the force where character has been compromised may have an inquiry as to the truth of any charges made against him c any officer dismissed from the permanent police force shall be ineligible for reappointment or restoration to the force  secs 21112140  reserved article ii  probationary patrol officers appointmentqualifications of applicants a candidate for appointment as a probationary patrol officer shall qualify as follows 1 he shall be a citizen of the united states 2 he shall have attained his 21st birthday 3 he shall have satisfactorily completed four years of accredited high school or the equivalent thereof 4 he shall be able to meet the weight standard in effect at the time of the application 5 he shall be in good health organically sound and shall have no defective vision or hearing and he shall pass such tests and physical examination as may be required by the state municipal police academy 6 if he has served in the armed forces of the united states or a foreign country he shall have received a discharge therefrom under honorable conditions 7 he shall be a person of good reputation in the community and be free from intemperate or immoral habits he shall not have been convicted of a felony misdemeanor or serious motor vehicle offense or have habitually consorted with criminals or persons of ill repute or have been engaged in or connected with any illegal or illicit business  sameinterview and evaluation all applicants for appointment as probationary patrol officers shall be interviewed and evaluated by a screening board of superior officers who shall rate all applicants and shall list them in the numerical order of standing as to their qualification for a police career every applicant shall be investigated by the police department to determine his background reputation and general adaptability for police work  sametesting of applicants every applicant for appointment as a probationary patrol officer shall be tested for educational background and experience in spelling word definitions english comprehension arithmetic history geography and knowledge of current events every applicant shall be given intelligence and psychological tests to determine his attitudes and aptitudes for a police career  sameapplicants to meet current physical standards every applicant for appointment as a probationary patrol officer prior to appointment by the town administrator shall meet the current standards established for the medical examination and the physical fitness tests as required by the state municipal police academy  sameoath upon appointment as a probationary patrol officer every appointee shall swear the following oath i ___________ do solemnly swear to uphold the constitutions of the united states and the state of rhode island that i will execute my duties as a probationary patrol officer to the best of my ability faithfully and impartially enforcing all laws and ordinances zealously guarding the constitutional rights of all persons and promptly obeying the orders of the officers appointed over me all in accordance with the regulations of the bristol police department so help me god  training persons selected as probationary patrol officers shall undergo a schedule of training for a prescribed period of time the training schedule shall be divided in such a manner as to provide for formal instructions onthejob training and final testing to ascertain each candidates abilities  length of probationary period  separation from force during probationary period probationary patrol officers may be separated from the police force at any time during the probationary period of one year without trial or hearing when the town administrator on the recommendation of the chief of police deems such separation to be for the good of the force  appointment to permanent status after successful completion of the probationary period and on the recommendation of the chief of police the town administrator on the recommendation of the chief of police may appoint probationary patrol officers to permanent status in the police department each appointee shall reswear the oath described in section 2145 omitting the word probationary in the parentheses  secs 21492180  reserved article iii  police reserve reserve created there is hereby created within the town a town police reserve the town police reserve shall be under the direction and control of the chief of police or his designee  1636 appointment and number a members to the town police reserve shall be appointed by the town council annually in the month of january to serve for a term of one year the maximum number of appointed members shall be 40 b former but retired town police officers who are added to the reserve by virtue of labor contract shall be in addition to the maximum number and shall be exempt from other entrance qualifications set forth in this article they must otherwise continue to qualify and are subject to all other ordinances rules and regulations as are appointed members  qualifications qualification for membership or continuing membership shall be the following 1 a member must be a resident of the town 2 a member must not be less than 21 years of age 3 a member must be of a weight proportionate with the members build 4 a member must never have been convicted of a crime 5 a member at the members expense must successfully pass a physical examination by the police surgeon such examination shall follow the standards established by the national association of police and fire surgeons 6 a member must be a high school graduate or its equivalent and shall be tested for educational background and experience in spelling word definitions english comprehension arithmetic history geography and knowledge of current events every applicant shall be given intelligence and psychological tests to determine his attitudes and aptitudes for this service and he must also pass a physical agility test 7 a member must be of acceptable personal integrity and of good moral background as determined by investigation and recommendation 8 a member shall be required to qualify annually with the firearm with which such member is to be armed by the town police firearms instructor or an instructor designated by the chief of police 9 a member at the members expense must have the necessary uniforms and equipment and must agree to accept the police details assigned 10 a member must have worked voluntarily at least four hours per month as a police reserve during the year preceding reappointment as a community service 11 a member must also have been appointed by the town council to be a special constable under gl 195  45168  exceptions to certain qualifications persons currently serving in the police reserve on  shall belong to the towns police reserve and shall be exempt from the provisions set forth in section 21832 3 and 6  oath every member shall take the following oath i ___________ do solemnly swear to uphold the constitutions of the united states and of the state of rhode island that i will execute my duties as a police reserve to the best of my ability faithfully and impartially enforcing all the laws and ordinances zealously guarding the constitutional rights of all persons and promptly obeying the orders of the officers appointed over me all in accordance with the regulations of the bristol police department so help me god  training all members of the reserve shall successfully complete the reserve training school within one year of appointment and shall attend and be retrained a minimum of once every five years school set up by the state municipal police academy or inservice training there will be no exceptions to this section  powers  bearing of firearms when on active duty members shall have the powers of police officers except as otherwise limited by ordinances of the town or laws of the state or the united states members shall not on any occasion bear firearms unless specifically authorized to do so by the chief of police and only while in full uniform  chief of police to promulgate rules the chief of police is authorized to promulgate rules and regulations subject to approval by the town administrator for the operation and training of the town police reserve and not inconsistent with ordinances of the town  secs 218921100  reserved article iv  retirement and insurance plan footnotes  2  editors note of the acts and resolves of 1938 a group insurance contract or contracts covering members of the police department of the town b the police department retirement plan fund shall be available only to full time permanent members of the
