wires unless it is contaminated with hazardous heavy metals or chemicals or mercury thermometers or pcbcontaining florescent bulbs recyclable materials mixed recyclable materials means certain materials that are required to be separated from municipal solid waste for processing as specified by rhode island general law hereinafter rigl tit 23 chs 188 189 and 19 as established by the rhode island resource recovery corporation hereinafter rirrc and the rhode island department of environmental management hereinafter ridem the materials to be included may change from time to time depending upon new technologies economic conditions waste stream characteristics environmental effects or mutual agreement between the state and municipalities solid waste means garbage refuse rubbish and other discarded solid materials generated by residential institution commercial industrial and agricultural sources but not including solids or dissolved material in domestic sewage or sewage sludge nor hazardous waste as defined in the hazardous waste management act rigl ch 191 white goods means major kitchen or laundry appliances regardless of color including but not limited to stoves washers refrigerators and dryers nothing in this definition shall waive compliance with the rules and regulations for generation transportation storage and disposal of hazardous waste    cross reference definitions generally  12 authority and administration a the director shall oversee the implementation of this chapter b the director shall collect all fees provided for under this article and shall promptly remit collection fees to the towns finance director  authority vested in the director to promulgate rules and regulations authority shall be vested in the director to promulgate and publish rules and regulations to effectuate the objectives and requirements of this chapter including but not limited to governing the town transfer station operations establishing hours of operation defining of the types of materials which may be deposited in the town transfer station operations controlling issuance of permits and setting standards as to identification of those seeking permits and access to the town transfer station operations curbside pickup and mandatory recycling  amendment of rules and regulations any enactments or amendments to the rules and regulations shall be sent to the town council for review and shall be placed on the agenda of a regular town council meeting as a consent agenda item and shall not take effect until after said meeting the town council by motion may reject in part or in whole such amendments to the rules and regulations  penalty for violation of chapter and enforcement any person or corporation whether as principal agent employee or otherwise who violates or is the owner of property in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be required to remove the violation as soon as practicable and issued a warning for the first offense and fined up to $2500 for a second offense up to $10000 for a third offense and up to $50000 for each and every offense thereafter such fines to be paid to the town each day of the existence of any violation shall be deemed a separate offense the director shall have the authority to enforce this chapter to notify the party of the offending violation and to levy such fines with appeal thereupon to the municipal court      fees and charges all fees and charges for town transfer station permits and operations and any other waste disposal related products and services shall be established by town council resolution and administered by the department of public works  secs 2472435  reserved article ii  collection and disposal collection by private collection service a private persons may be authorized to collect garbage and refuse  provided that such collection is performed in accordance with this article and produces no objectionable conditions in or on the streets b private collectors except persons under contract to the town for such collection before engaging in such business shall be licensed by the town council there shall be a fee each year for each vehicle used in such service all permits shall expire on december 31 of the year in which they were issued but may be renewed annually no permit shall be transferred except with the approval of the town council such license may be revoked by the town council following a hearing and upon receipt of evidence that the nature of collection or disposal is not in conformity with the requirements or such further rules as may be adopted c private scavenging on the street is prohibited no person shall overhaul the contents of receptacles of solid waste or recyclable materials set upon the sidewalks for collection d all vehicles employed in the collection of garbage shall be kept watertight and covered at all times vehicles employed in the collection of refuse shall be so equipped as to prevent any material from blowing or dropping onto the highway pursuant to rigl  31259 and 312510 e no licensee shall collect any garbage or refuse from any premises until permission has been given by the owner or occupant to do so    transportation no person except those holding a contract therefor with the town shall remove solid waste recyclable materials or other materials from any public street court lane or way without first obtaining a permit from the town council  and provided further that they shall remove and transport the material therein mentioned in accordance with reasonable rules and regulations as may be established by the town council all permits shall expire on december 31 of the year in which they were issued but may be renewed annually they may be revoked by the town council at any time for cause no permit shall be transferred except with the approval of the town council containers or vehicles used for the transporting of solid waste recyclable materials or other materials shall be watertight and shall be securely covered with tightfitting covers which shall be kept closed and securely fastened while the vehicle or receptacle is being moved from one place to another any vehicle or receptacle used for the transportation of refuse shall be well painted on the outside and kept clean no such receptacle shall be used for any other purpose    disposal by incineration or grinding on premises where accumulated a this chapter shall not prohibit the disposal of combustible refuse and garbage in the home or commercial establishments by incineration if no smoke or odors are produced that are classed as nuisances or hazards b the grinding of food wastes into water carried pulp which is then transported to the household or commercial plumbing system and then into the municipal sanitary sewer system or private sewer is permissible    disposal by individual resident nothing in this article shall be so construed as to prevent a resident from disposing of solid waste recyclable materials or other materials from their own household without a permit from the director  provided however that they shall remove transport or dispose of such material only in conformance with this article and the rules and regulations enacted by the director  secs 24402475  reserved article iii  transfer station town exemptions town vehicles on town business are permitted access to effective date of dec 30 2017 secs 2412124130  reserved article v  plastic bags purpose the purpose of this article is to improve the environment in bristol and the health safety and welfare of its residents by reducing the number of plastic and paper bags being used and by encouraging the use of reusable carryout bags and banning the use of plastic bags for retail checkout of goods retail establishments are encouraged to make reusable carryout bags available for sale  definitions as used in this article the following terms shall have the meanings indicated carryout bag means a bag used by the customer at the point of sale for the purpose of removing products purchased from retail establishment carryout bag does not include plastic barrier bags doubleopening plastic bags or plastic bags measuring larger than 28 inches by 36 inches doubleopening plastic bag means any thin plastic bag with a double opening top and bottom to protect clothing or other items for transport paper bag means a paper bag that is fully recyclable overall and contains a minimum of 40 percent postconsumer recycled content and contains no old growth fiber plastic bag means a bag where any portion of the bag is made of plastic including but not limited to those called biodegradable compostable or oxobiodegradable plastic barrier bag means any thin plastic bag with a single opening used to 1 transport fruit vegetables nuts grains small hardware items or other items selected by customers to the point of sale  2 contain or wrap fresh or frozen foods meat or fish whether prepackaged or not  3 contain or wrap flowers potted plants or other items where damage to a good or contamination of other goods placed together in the same bag may be a problem  or 4 contain unwrapped prepared foods or bakery goods recyclable plastic means plastic that meets the current rhode island resource recovery corporations standards retail sales establishment means any enterprise whereby the sale or transfer to a customer of goods in exchange for payment occurring in retail stores farmers markets flea markets and restaurants this does not include sales of goods at yard sales tag sales other sales by residents at their homes and sales by nonprofit organizations reusable carryout bag means a bag with handles which are stitched and not heatfused that is specifically designed and manufactured for multiple reuse the bag must be made of washable cloth other durable woven or nonwoven fabric or durable plastic film that is recyclable plastic with a minimum thickness of four mils  regulations a other than reusable carryout bags as provided in this article no retail sales establishment shall make available any plastic carryout bags either complimentary or for a fee b all retail establishments that provide plastic barrier bags andor double opening bags must offer a recycling opportunity on site and must recycle any plastic collected in accordance with current laws c nothing in this section shall preclude persons engaged in retail sales from making reusable carryout bags or paper bags available for sale to customers  enforcement  violations and penalties a this article shall be implemented administered and enforced by the town police department or any other town department or division designated by the town administrator b upon being made aware of a potential violation of this article the town police department or other designee shall investigate and determine whether a violation has occurred c if the investigation confirms that a violation has occurred then the bristol town police department or other designee shall give written notice to the owner of the property the owners agent or the person performing such violation that the violation is occurring and must stop d such notice shall be in writing and may be served upon a person to whom it is directed either by delivering it personally to him or her or by posting same upon a conspicuous portion of the property and sending a copy of same by certified mail to the person to whom the notice is directed e the owner the owners agent or the person performing the violation is responsible for confirming in writing that the violation has ceased to the town police department or other designee within 14 days of receipt of the notice f a second violation after the 14day response period of the first violation and within one year of the receipt of the confirmation that the violation had ceased shall incur a penalty of $15000 g a third violation within one year of the second and any subsequent violations shall incur a penalty of $30000 h each occurrence of a violation after the first and each day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate violation and may be cited as such  appeals any violation charged under this article may be appealed in writing to the town administrator within 14 days of receipt of a written notice of violation the town administrator may waive the individual violation or the requirements of this article on showing of good cause or undue hardship  effective date the provisions of this article shall become effective  the provisions of this article shall automatically expire on  if not renewed by act of the town council  streets sidewalks and other public places footnotes  1  cross reference any ordinance dedicating naming establishing locating relocating opening over the excavated area and 50 feet on either side of the excavation including cold planing grinding and edge matching with a minimum settlement period of three months and a maximum of six months before permanent repairs are made  and left in a condition satisfactory to and approved by the director of public works d penalties except in emergency situations any person who excavates digs or cuts construction dumpsters a generally  as used in this section the word dumpster shall mean any container which is used for the collection and disposal of bulk trash refuse recyclable materials or other kinds of waste and which may be of the open or enclosed variety and is typically hoisted onto a specifically equipped truck for transporting said waste to a designated facility dumpsters are typically used for commercial and industrial land uses b location of dumpsters  no dumpster shall be placed so that it blocks any public sidewalk no dumpster shall be located on a public street or alley unless a permit is obtained from the director of the department of public works if permitted and the dumpster is placed on the public street or alley the dumpster shall be directly in front of or on the side of the property address utilizing the dumpster additionally a dumpster placed in the street shall 1 not be more than 12 inches from the curb  2 not obstruct driveways of abutting properties  3 not obstruct traffic  4 have a reflector or reflective area of not less than 36 square inches at each end additionally a dumpster shall not be placed on the public street if onstreet parking for vehicles is not allowed at that location c time limit the time limits for the maintenance of dumpsters is as follows 1 residential zoning districts during any sixmonth period a dumpster and any replacement dumpster shall be placed for a total of not more than 14 days in any sixmonth period if placed on the street and not more than 30 days in any sixmonth period if placed elsewhere the time limits prescribed in this subsection do not apply to private dumpsters that service the regular and ordinary disposal needs of multihousehold dwellings 2 commercial zoning districts a dumpster and any replacement dumpster placed under this section and not in a public street may remain on the site as long as required a dumpster or any replacement dumpster placed upon a public street may be placed for not more than a total of 14 days in any sixmonth period 3 industrial zoning districts a dumpster or any replacement dumpster placed under this section may remain on the site as long as needed but not to exceed a total of 18 months but not to exceed 14 days if on a public street or sidewalk d sanitation the following requirements shall be maintained while the dumpster is on or at the site 1 the area around the dumpster shall be kept free of debris and litter  2 any dumpster into which animal or vegetable waste or material has been dumped or deposited shall be removed or emptied within 24 hours  3 any dumpster producing or causing noxious foul or offensive odors shall be immediately removed or cleaned to eliminate the odor  and 4 a full dumpster shall be removed from the property within two days e usage a dumpster shall only be used to contain and remove debris and material generated at the location where the dumpster is placed f identification the name and 24hour seven days per week telephone number of the owner of the dumpster andor the company that is responsible for the dumpster shall be displayed in a weather proof manner on the dumpster g permit required a permit shall be required for a dumpster the permit shall be obtained from the director of the public works department after paying the required fee which shall be set by council resolution h abatement any dumpster not in compliance with this section is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and may be abated by the city at the owners or responsible persons expense abatement shall at the citys option include the removal andor the emptying of the dumpster i violations  penalties  enforcement of this section shall be in accordance with section 28407 of this entitled enforcement and penalties this section shall be valid for the day of the fourth of july parade in any year g suspension or revocation of license and penalty for violations any infraction of this section may be grounds for suspension or revocation of this license for just cause and subject to later review by the town council the town administrator may immediately suspend any sidewalk license in the interest of public safety in addition the town council may upon a hearing suspend revoke or modify a sidewalk license andor impose fines individuals or businesses found in violation of the provisions of this section are also subject to a fine not to exceed $10000 for the first offense a fine not to exceed $50000 for the second and subsequent offenses in addition to any other fine assessed pursuant to this      secs 25162520  reserved article ii  protection and maintenance of trees in public places purpose and intent the town council finds that trees are economically beneficial to the town and the community in attracting residents visitors and new industry and further that healthy trees properly located enhance the value and marketability of property  enhance the quality of life in the community  and promote the stability of neighborhoods by providing a healthy and more beautiful environment in which to live the town council further finds that the town of bristol has a great variety of both tree and shrub species which should be protected and maintained in order to preserve the public health safety and general welfare  short title this article shall be known and may be cited as the tree ordinance of the town this article regulates the protection maintenance and planting of trees in public places and authorizes the conservation commission to act as the tree commission  scope this article shall regulate the protection maintenance removal and planting of trees in public streets and other public places excluding public school grounds town parks and the town beach this ordinance shall not be applicable to the care and control of trees and shrubs on roads under the control of the department of transportation nor those in public parks or grounds which are under the jurisdiction and control of the department of environmental management nothing in this ordinance shall be inconsistent with state regulations as set forth in rigl title 2 for purposes of this article the term tree shall mean any living selfsupporting wood plant that has a well defined stems with a caliper of at least two inches at 45 feet from ground level  regulation by the town administrator the town administrator shall retain jurisdiction for the maintenance and preservation of trees and all forestry functions including the care and removal of trees within the jurisdiction of the town the town administrator shall review all requests for permission for any planting removal or trimming of trees within any public right of way in reviewing each request the town administrator shall obtain a report from the tree warden written permission shall be granted by the town administrator and such permission may include reasonable conditions consistent with the purposes of this article the master tree management plan described in section 2528 and the recommendations of the tree warden all planting removal or trimming of trees within any public right of way shall be conducted by or under the supervision of the tree warden  tree wardenappointment and qualifications a tree warden shall be appointed by the town council pursuant by the town charter and title 2 of the rhode island general laws the tree warden shall be a state licensed arborist or if not a licensed arborist within six months of his assuming office the tree warden shall become a state licensed arborist  sameterm of office and vacancies a tree warden whose appointment has been approved by the director of the environmental management shall hold office until the first day of march in the year following his appointment and until his successor is duly appointed and approved any vacancy that may occur in the office of the tree warden shall be filled by the town council by the appointment of some person to serve for the remainder of the term subject to the approval of the director  samepowers and duties the powers and duties of the tree warden shall conform to those duties and responsibilities outlined in gl  214121410 as may be amended and include the following 1 enforce all provisions of state and local laws for the preservation of trees and shrubs in accordance with this article 2 be responsible for all planting removal or trimming of trees within any public right of way within the town 3 shall serve as a member of the tree commission  authority of the bristol conservation commission function as tree commission a the bristol conservation commission existing as an advisory commission under the authority of the town council shall function as the tree commission the tree warden shall be a member of the tree commission b the tree commission shall prepare in accordance with this article a master tree management plan master plan and recommend the same to the town council for adoption the master plan shall be a fiveyear systemized tree management plan which makes recommendations for the regulation of the cultivation and planting of trees the master plan shall be revised every five years the goals and recommendations of the ri urban and community forest plan state guide plan element no 156 shall be used as a guide when developing the master plan the fiveyear master plan shall include but is not limited to the following 1 tree inventory andor management plan  2 tree planting plan  3 tree maintenance plan  4 plans for a public education program  5 budgetary forecast  and 6 funding opportunities the tree commission shall also prepare an annual action plan yearly plan which shall include specific details on maintenance needs planting needs public education and an annual evaluation of the previous years activities c the commission shall prepare budgetary recommendations annually and recommend the same to the town council for adoption d the tree commission shall be responsible for developing administrative guidelines as a supplement to this article which will address the day to day procedures and specifications for tree protection maintenance removal and planting of trees in public places e the tree commission shall communicate and work with civic and public interest groups concerned with tree care management preservation and planting as well as with public utility companies and coordinate their activities with all necessary town officers commissions and boards in the following areas 1 the development of administrative procedures to regulate and manage day to day forestry functions in public places 2 assurance that all forestry functions are carried out consistent with the insurance of public safety protection of the aesthetics of public places and the preservation of the value and health of bristols trees  protection of trees within public rightsofway the following special restrictions shall apply concerning any tree located in a public rightofway within the scope of this article 1 no person shall deposit place store or maintain any stone brick sand material concrete or other materials that may impede the free passage of water air and fertilizer to the roots of any tree growing therein except by written permit from the tree warden 2 no person shall preclude the percolation of water or nutrients and gaseous exchange vital to a trees survival by placing any impervious materials within the confines of the tree well opening 3 no person shall move any building or any other large object that may injure public trees or parts thereof without first obtaining the written approval of the tree warden 4 all trees within a public rightofway that are within 30 feet of any excavation or construction of any buildingstructure or street work shall be guarded length of the project with good substantial frame or box not less than four feet high the owners of the property where the excavation or construction occurs shall be responsible for compliance with this provision of the article  enforcement replacement penalties a all trees removed destroyed or damaged as a result of unauthorized activity shall be replaced at the expense of the responsible person or persons replacement of trees shall be made with 35 to 6 inch caliper trees as directed by the tree commission following consultation with the tree warden the total replacement in caliper inches shall equal the total caliper inches removed all new andor transplanted trees and shrubs shall be guaranteed by the responsible person for one year b the tree warden shall investigate suspected violations of this article upon determining that a violation exists the tree warden shall within 15 days give written notice of the violation to the person or persons responsible a copy of such notice shall also be sent to the tree commission c the persons have five days to respond to any notice of violation a person receiving a notice of violation may either deny in writing that a violation exists and request reconsideration by the tree warden citing specific reasons for this request or cause the violation to be cured where a reconsideration is requested the tree warden shall respond promptly in writing citing facts of the case and applicable ordinance provisions if the owner fails to take any action in a timely manner monetary penalties may be assessed d any persons found in violation of this article may be fined up to $50000 for each offense such fine to inure to the town and be made a part of the tree planting account the fine shall relate to the seriousness of the offense each day of the existence of any violation shall be deemed a separate offense the tree warden is hereby empowered to levy such fines with written appeal thereupon to the municipal court e wherein a 15day period a responsible person fails to remove the violation andor pay all fines in full that have been levied the tree warden shall either cause the violation to be cured or file an action in the municipal court to i compel payment of all fines andor ii institute other appropriate action in the municipal court to prevent enjoin abate or remove such violation or compel compliance with the provisions of this article any costs associated with correcting the violation andor any unpaid fines and court costs may be filed by the town as liens on the property except where the municipal court provides otherwise appeals from decisions of the municipal court shall be in accordance with section 2216 of the town code  emergencies the requirements of this article may be waived by the director of public works in the case of emergencies such as winter storms tropical storms hurricanes or other natural or manmade disasters so that they in no way shall hinder private or public works to restore order to the town all emergencies shall to the degree practical follow the standards of this article  exemptions the requirements of this article shall not apply to decisions of the director of public works or hisher designee in carrying out the duties and responsibilities of his or her office routine andor emergency activities of the department of public works which may be required to ensure the public safety shall be exempt from the requirements of this article  interference with the tree warden no person shall hinder prevent delay or interfere with the tree warden or any of his or her assistants while they are engaged in carrying out the implementation of this article  provided however that nothing herein shall be construed as an intent to prohibit the pursuit of any remedy legal or equitable in any court of competent jurisdiction or the protection of property rights by the owner of any property within town  effective date this article and any amendment thereto shall be declared to be of immediate necessity for the preservation of public peace health and safety and shall be in full force and effective from and after its passage and publication as provided by law  severability if any one or more sections of this ordinance shall for any reason be adjudged unconstitutional or otherwise invalid the judgment shall not effect impair or invalidate the remaining provisions  relationship to other ordinances nothing in this article shall be construed to restrict amend repeal or otherwise limit the application or enforcement of the zoning ordinance or the subdivision and land development regulations of the town  subdivisions footnotes  1  cross reference any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the town for tax deferral shall be presented to the tax assessor on or before the last day upon which sworn accounts of their ratable estate are required to be filed pursuant to of title 44 of the rhode island general laws for each year for which such deferral is claimed provided however that in the initial year of this program a timely application may be filed by  such application shall be on a form provided by the tax assessor and shall be accompanied by such other forms of evidence as the tax assessor may reasonably require to establish eligibility for the deferral program all applications must be signed by all persons or entities having a present legal or equitable ownership interest in the property    definitions for the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply base year the year before the year for which the application for deferral of taxes is first claimed household income total income from whatever source derived including but not limited to realized capital gains pension annuity retirement and social security benefits received by all persons living in the dwelling except the livein caretaker or caregiver who has another primary residence household income shall be determined on the basis of the calendar year ending with the date of assessment for the tax year for which the deferral is claimed resident a person legally domiciled within the town for a period of at least 20 years ending with the date of assessment for the year for which the deferral is claimed and who continues to be legally domiciled in the town during the period for which the deferral is claimed residency must be for at least nine months per annum mere seasonal or temporary residence in town of whatever duration shall not constitute domicile for the purposes of this section absence from the town for 12 months shall be prima facie evidence of termination or abandonment of domicile the burden of establishing domicile in the town shall be on the applicant qualified property an owner occupied singlefamily residence with no accessory family dwelling unit or commercial component or use qualified resident a resident of the town of bristol who 1 is 65 years of age or older as of the assessment date for the year for which the deferral is claimed  2 is one of the lawful owners of the property for which the deferral is claimed and has continuously been a lawful owner of that property for a period not less than 20 years ending on the date of assessment for the year for which the deferral is claimed  3 occupies the subject property at his or her principal residence  4 who has a household income of not less than $1000000 but not more than $5000000    payment the amount of any taxes deferred pursuant hereto shall be a lien on the property from the date of assessment and shall be payable upon the occurrence of any one of the following 1 within six months of the death of the qualified resident subject to exception set forth in section 2726 2 transfer or conveyance of the property to any one other than a person who was a qualified resident and joint applicant at the time the deferral was first claimed 3 written request of the applicant to be removed from the program    title if title to the property is held by two or more persons the terms  qualified resident   owneroccupant  and applicant shall refer to all such persons each such person must meet the eligibility requirements provided in this section except in the following cases 1 in the case or property held jointly by husband and wife the property if otherwise eligible for deferral shall not be disallowed upon the grounds that one spouse is not 65 years or older or has not resided in bristol for the required 20 years 2 a deferral under this section shall not be disallowed if the owneroccupant has only a life estate in the property or if the property is in the name of a parent or one or more children or a living trust for the benefit of the otherwise qualified resident and the owners submit an affidavit that the qualified resident is principal owner or present beneficiary and title is held in that manner for estate planning purposes only    transfer to widowwidower a in the event that the death of a qualified resident results in title being vested in a surviving widow or widower and at the time of said death the widow or widower is a qualified resident said death shall result in only the following portion of the deferred taxes becoming due and payable 1 those taxes which would otherwise have been due and payable in the years prior to the lawful marriage of the qualified resident and the surviving widowwidower b the remainder of the deferred taxes become due and payable  1 within six months of the death of the widowwidower 2 transfer or conveyance of the property to anyone other than a person who was a qualified resident and joint applicant at the time the deferral was first claimed 3 written request of the applicant to be removed from the program    other exemptions any applicant qualifying for tax deferral pursuant to this section shall remain eligible for any and all tax exemptions allowed by the town for which they are eligible and have wholesalers inventory exemption a definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning inventory or stock in trade means the merchandise kept on hand for sale under normal or regular course of wholesale business wholesaler means and includes a person partnership corporation or other business entity engaged in the business of selling goods for subsequent resale by its customers except as provided in subsection b of this section no distinction shall be drawn between 1 a wholesaler all or a portion of the sales of which are sales to one or more customers affiliated with the wholesaler  and 2 a wholesaler the sales of which are exclusively sales to customers not affiliated with the wholesaler a wholesaler shall be considered affiliated with customers if its control is controlled by or is under common control with the customers b calculation of wholesale and retail sales percentages if a wholesaler sold inventory or stock in trade both at wholesale and at retail in the preceding calendar year the tax assessor shall assess on the same basis as a retailers inventory or stock in trade as of december 31 of that year to the extent permitted by applicable law notwithstanding any freeze or assessed valuation or exemption permitted under this section that portion of inventory or stock in trade of the wholesaler which shall be equal to the percentage of the wholesalers total sales during the preceding calendar year that were at retail for the purposes of this section sales at retail shall not include sales to employees of the wholesaler or to the employees of its affiliates if retail sales are less than one percent of total sales during the calendar year it shall be deemed that no sales were made at retail during the year all sales of the wholesaler to a customer which is an affiliated entity shall be deemed to be retail sales for purposes of this section if more than half of the dollar volume of the sales of the affiliated entity are made within the town c duration of exemption for 25 years after this section is passed and approved the tax assessor shall exempt a wholesalers inventory from taxes where the wholesaler requests the exemption from the tax assessor and complies with verification procedures as established by the tax assessor 16 exemption of persons over the age of 65 years a entitlements and amounts for the purposes of this subsection see section 279 b qualifications for the 870 2003 $ 695 2004 $ 520 2005 $ 345 2006 and thereafter no tax authorized    volunteer firefighterems tax incentive program a purpose the town recognizes that volunteering to be a fire fighter is one of the most demanding volunteer activities an individual can undertake due to significant fire service training requirements and time taken away from family work and other volunteer activities the town desires to retain its cadre of volunteer fire fighters to provide the services necessary for the public health and safety of the town as well as to recruit new volunteers therefore the town ordains tax incentives to volunteer fire fighters as set forth herein b tax abatement the town may grant a tax abatement to members of the bristol volunteer fire department fire department said qualifications shall be reviewed and approved by the town council annually commencing in 2018 c available amount of relief the town council may reduce the real property tax obligation or motor vehicle and trailer excise tax obligation of volunteer firefighters and emergency medical services personnel up to $250000 for any fiscal year the fire chief shall prepare a sliding scale of abatements for town council approval based on the qualifications of the applicant d eligible volunteer the tax abatement may be made available to volunteers on a sliding scale provided the following minimum eligibility requirements are met as determined by the fire chief 1 completion of recruit school and participation as an active firefighter  2 training to the hazardous materials operation level  3 attendance at a minimum number of drills per year  4 attendance at a minimum number of emergency responses per year  5 maintaining a minimum medical training level of cpr and first aid  6 if a line officer presence at a minimum number of department drills  e additional incentives the amount of the abatement may be increased up to the amount provided for in subsection c hereof for individuals who earn the following achievements 1 firefighter iii certification  2 fire officer certification  3 fire instructor certification  4 length of service milestones  5 rank achievements  6 accredited ems or fire certifications f requirements of service individuals shall be entitled to a tax abatement only if he or she shall have been certified by the fire department to be eligible in accordance with established policies rules and regulations for the year for which the abatement is claimed together with due evidence that he or she is entitled to such abatement g eligible property eligible property shall not include property for which taxes are delinquent to be eligible a property must 1 be any real or personal property for which the eligible volunteer holds title  or 2 be any real property for which a person or legal entity other than the eligible volunteer holds title provided that such real property shall be the eligible volunteers principal residence and provided that such eligible volunteer shall provide documentation to prove to the satisfaction of the assessor that the eligible volunteer currently pays or is legally obligated to pay town property taxes on such real property  or 3 be any personal property for which the title is held by a person or legal entity other than the eligible volunteer provided that such eligible volunteer shall provide documentation to prove to the satisfaction of the assessor that the eligible volunteer currently pays or is legally obligated to pay town property taxes on such personal property 4 in the event that a person applying as active status does not own property within the town a cash equivalent as approved by the town council may be paid up to the minimum amount eligible to be earned h reporting period the calendar year 2018 shall be deemed the initial reporting on or before january 31st of each year commencing with 201 the fire chief shall provide to the town council an accounting of all eligible participants as well as a census of current and new volunteers during the reporting period i application of abatement the tax abatement earned for any given year shall be credited as a reduction in the tax obligation of the following fiscal year j application any eligible volunteer or his or her authorized agent shall file an annual application for tax relief under this article with the town assessor prior to march 15th on a form or forms prescribed and furnished by the town the applicant or his or her authorized agent shall sign a sworn affidavit affirming the accuracy of the statements in the application when the town assessor is satisfied that the applicant qualifies under this article the assessor shall compute the amount of such tax relief and provide a full report to the town council before april 10th and cause certificates of tax abatement to be issued in such form as to permit the tax collector to reduce the amount of tax levied against the eligible volunteer and make proper record thereof and a copy thereof shall be delivered to the applicant the tax abatement shall be applied proportionately to the tax payments k review of application the assessor may at any time inquire into the right of the applicant to an abatement or any continuation of the abatement and for that purpose may require the filing of a new application or submission of such proof as he or she shall deem necessary to determine the right of the applicant to an abatement in the original instance or any continuance of the abatement l characterization of abatement the amount by which a persons tax liability is reduced shall not be considered income wages or employment for the purposes of taxation m expiration date this section and all of its benefits shall expire  unless reenacted by the town council prior thereto  secs 27132725  reserved article ii  tax exemption for solar energy systems findings pursuant to rigl  44321 as amended solar energy systems may be exempt from taxation the town council finds as follows 1 that it would be in the public interest to exempt from taxation certain solar energy systems as provided for in section 2728  2 tax exemptions should be reserved for solar energy systems designed primarily to generate approximately the same amount of energy consumed on the subject property  3 tax exemptions should not be available to individuals or entities using solar energy systems primarily to produce energy for sale unless the energy generated and sold is in an amount substantially offset by energy purchased for use on the subject property  definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning average consumption shall mean 125 percent of the average electric consumption on the property for the qualifying period or 125 percent of the estimated electrical consumption on the property certified by affidavit from a licensed professional engineer nameplate capacity shall mean the total maximum intended full load sustained output of the systems inverter or inverters as determined by the manufacturer due to the latitude and climate of bristol the average actual capacity is deemed to be onequarter of such total nameplate capacity qualifying period shall mean the 36 months prior to the application for exemption as provided for in section 2729 solar energy shall mean energy that is generated from photovoltaics solar energy system shall mean equipment or apparatus designed to harness or contain solar energy  exemptions solar energy systems shall be exempt from taxation as follows 1 solar energy systems on residential structures of four units or fewer are exempted from taxation in an amount equal to the additional amount assessed to the value of any property as a result of a solar energy system not to exceed $2500000 2 solar energy systems on residential structures of five units or more and commercial and industrial structures are exempted from taxation in an amount equal to the additional amount assessed to the value of any property as a result of a solar energy system and subject to the additional limitations set forth in section 2729b below  application a application for tax exemption for solar energy systems must be made to the town tax assessor in a manner to be established by the tax assessor b owners of solar energy systems exempted by section 27282 shall include with their application evidence that the solar energy systems nameplate capacity is not in excess of four times the average consumption such evidence shall include either 1 utility bills showing electricity consumption for the qualifying period  or 2 an affidavit from a licensed professional engineer certifying the projected electrical consumption on the property c property owners must reapply upon reassessment of the value of the property on which the solar energy system is situated  relationship to other ordinances nothing in this article shall be construed to restrict amend repeal or otherwise limit the application or enforcement of the zoning ordinance or the subdivision and land development regulations of the town  secs 27312740  reserved article iii  board of tax assessment review footnotes  2  editors note adopted  redesignated former art ii as art iii as set out herein charter reference board of tax assessment review  606 cross reference boards commissions and committees  291 et seq composition  terms  appointment  officers  vacancies there shall be a board of tax assessment review consisting of three members appointed by the council to serve for threeyear staggered terms no more than two of whom shall be of the same political party at any one time all appointments made upon the expiration of terms or to fill vacancies shall be made from lists of names requested by the council from the party chairman from whose party appointment is to be made any such list shall contain at least three times the number of names as there are appointments to be made from that list each appointment shall be made for a threeyear term and thereafter until his successor is appointed such board shall elect one of their number as chairperson and one as secretary if a member of such board shall cease to be a resident of the town his office shall thereby become vacant 111 tax assessor the tax assessor serving as an exofficio advisor shall attend meetings of the board wherein an appeal is heard but shall not be entitled to vote therein the tax assessor shall serve as the secretary to the board 112 powers and duties a all persons who pursuant to ri gen laws as amended are aggrieved by an assessment of taxes may within 30 days from the date the first tax payment is due file an appeal to the tax assessor the tax assessor has 45 days to review and render a decision b the board of tax assessment review shall hear and consider appeals from all aggrieved persons who pursuant to ri gen laws as amended are still aggrieved by the amounts of assessed valuation as determined after an appeal to the tax assessor provided such appeal is properly filed with the board within 90 days from the date the first tax payment is due the board has 90 days from the filing of the appeal to the board to hear the appeal the board shall hold hearings administer oaths and may receive testimony and exhibits the board has 30 days from the date the hearing was held in which to render a decision provided however the board may request and receive an extension as provided in ri general laws as amended if it shall appear that the valuation of any property has been erroneously or incorrectly assessed the board shall have the authority to order a correction such determination shall be certified by the board to the assessor whose duty it shall be to make such correction in the valuation as the board may determine c nothing in this section shall relieve the property owner from the obligation of installment payments while an appeal is pending 113   rules of procedure the procedure to be followed in the filing of appeals by all aggrieved persons who pursuant to ri gen laws as amended are aggrieved by an assessment of taxes is as follows 1 all appeals to the tax assessor and the board of assessment review shall be on petitions provided by such board blank petitions available from the board the tax assessor or the director of finances shall be filed with the tax assessor 2 all questions on such petition shall be answered completely 3 a separate petition shall be filed for each review requested 4 the landowner of record andor any aggrieved person must file all petitions or if this is not possible his mark or the signature of his legal representative must appear and his title must be affixed thereto 5 the petitioners will be notified of the time and place of any hearing 6 the landowner of record or his representative or the aggrieved person must appear at such hearing if persons other than the owner of record are to testify before the board of tax assessment then a written authorization filed by the landowner of record must be presented and recorded by the board 7 failure on the part of any petitioner or his legal representative to appear at the time and place designated by the board of assessment review for his petition to be heard without prior notification will be recorded as a default by nonappearance a any petition so recorded will not be reheard for a period of one fiscal year no petition may be resubmitted for any year for which a prior petition was recorded as a default due to nonappearance of the petitioner or his legal representative b there shall be no rehearing of any petition of one fiscal year unless the petitioner can present new or different evidence which could not have been presented to such board at the time of the original hearing or unless in the opinion of such board unusual circumstances warrant a rehearing 8 the procedure for rehearing shall be as follows a a new petition must be filed with the board of tax assessment with an accompanying list or brief of explanation b the board of assessment review at its regular meeting after the filing of the petition for rehearing will decide on the merits for a rehearing and the petitioner will be notified in writing of the findings and recommendations of such board 9 attorneys expert witnesses and any other persons may be presented by the petitioners to such board in the hearing of any petitions 10 the proceedings of the board of assessment review shall be recorded and kept in a minutes book provided by such board and shall be in the care custody and control of the secretary and available for public inspection 11 all decisions of the board of assessment review shall be by a vote 12 all petitioners will be notified in writing of the finding recommendations and decision of such board 114   appeal to superior court pursuant to of the rhode island general laws as amended an appeal for relief of an assessment may be taken by the filing of a petition in the superior court of bristol county within requirements of this chapter an authorization for the construction or maintenance of a building or structure or for the establishment or maintenance of a use of land which is prohibited by this chapter there shall be only two categories of variance a use variance or a dimensional variance 1 use variance permission to depart from the use requirements of this chapter where the applicant for the requested variance has shown by evidence upon the record that the subject land or structure cannot yield any beneficial use if it is to conform to the provisions of this chapter 2 dimensional variance permission to depart from the dimensional requirements of this chapter where the applicant for the requested relief has shown by evidence upon the record that there is no other reasonable alternative way to enjoy a legally permitted beneficial use of the subject property unless granted the requested relief from the dimensional regulations however the fact that a use may be more profitable or that a structure may be more valuable after the relief is granted shall not be grounds for relief vested rights means the right to initiate or continue the development of an approved project for a specified period of time under the regulations that were in effect at the time of approval even if after the approval the regulations change prior to the completion of the project open space and residential each district may include subdistricts districts may be combined      cross reference definitions generally  12 purpose of chapter these zoning regulations have been developed and will be maintained in accordance with the town comprehensive plan adopted  and amended  and as may be amended from time to time and are designed to address the following purposes 1 promote the public health safety and general welfare  2 provide for a range of uses and intensities of use appropriate to the character of the town and that reflect current and expected future needs  3 provide for orderly growth and development which recognizes a the goals and patterns of land use contained in the town comprehensive plan  b the natural characteristics of the land including its suitability for uses based on soil characteristics topography and susceptibility to surface water or groundwater pollution  c the values and dynamic nature of coastal and freshwater ponds the shoreline and freshwater and coastal wetlands  d the values of unique or valuable natural resources and features  e the availability and capacity of existing and planned public andor private services and facilities  f the need to shape and balance urban and rural development  and g the use of innovative development regulations and techniques 4 provide for the control protection andor abatement of air water groundwater and noise pollution and soil erosion and sedimentation 5 provide for the protection of the natural historic cultural and scenic character of the town 6 provide for the preservation and promotion of agricultural production forest silviculture aquaculture timber resources and open space 7 provide for the protection of public investment in transportation water stormwater management systems sewage treatment and disposal solid waste treatment and disposal schools recreation public facilities open space and other public requirements 8 promote a balance of housing choices for all income levels and groups to assure the health safety and welfare of all citizens and their rights to affordable accessible safe and sanitary housing 9 provide opportunities for the establishment of low and moderate income housing 10 promote safety from fire flood and other natural and manmade disasters 11 promote a high level of quality in design in the development of private and public facilities 12 promote implementation of the town comprehensive plan 13 provide for coordination of land uses with contiguous municipalities other municipalities the state and other agencies as appropriate especially with regard to resources and facilities that extend beyond town boundaries or have a direct impact on the town 14 provide for efficient review of development proposals to clarify and expedite the zoning approval process 15 provide for procedures for the administration of this chapter including but not limited to variances special use permits and modifications 16 promote sustainable development including the redevelopment of existing structures and facilities in preference to new development establishment of zoning districts for the purposes of this chapter the following zoning districts shall be designated 1 residential zoning districts residential zoning districts shall be as follows r80 zone the r80 zone is intended for very low density areas comprised of agricultural uses and single household detached structures with a minimum density of 80000 square feet per dwelling unit the purpose of this very low residential density zone is to ensure both that areas of town without adequate infrastructure are not developed beyond their capacity and to preserve natural historical and cultural resources of the town r40 zone this zone is intended for low density areas comprised of agricultural uses and single household detached structures with a minimum density of 40000 square feet per dwelling unit the purpose of this low residential density zone is to ensure both that areas of town without adequate infrastructure are not developed beyond their capacity and to preserve natural historical and cultural resources of the town r40w zone this zone is intended for low density residential areas comprised of single household detached structures in areas of town where there is a high probability of groundwater contamination because of proximity to a landfill or other contamination source with a minimum density of 40000 square feet per dwelling unit where public water is required r20 zone this zone is intended for medium density residential areas previously lacking infrastructure and already developed to this density or currently undeveloped and lacking infrastructure comprised of single household detached structures with a minimum density of 20000 square feet per dwelling unit r15 zone this zone is intended for medium density residential areas comprised of single household detached structures with a minimum density of 15000 square feet per dwelling unit where public sewer andor public water are provided r10 zone this zone is intended for high density residential areas comprised of single household and twohousehold structures with a minimum density of 10000 square feet per dwelling unit where public sewer andor public water are provided r10sw this zone is intended for high density residential areas comprised of single household and twohousehold structures in areas of town where there is a high probability of groundwater contamination because of proximity to a landfill or other contamination source with a minimum density of 10000 square feet per dwelling unit where public sewer and public water are required r8 zone this zone is intended for high density residential areas comprised of single household and twofamily household structures with a minimum density of 8000 square feet per dwelling unit r6 zone this r6 zone is intended for high density residential areas comprised of single household two household and multihousehold structures with a minimum density of 6000 square feet for the first dwelling unit and 4000 square feet per additional dwelling unit where public sewer and public water are required 2 commercial zoning districts commercial zoning districts shall be as follows lb zone limited business this zoning district is intended for mixed use including neighborhood commercial areas that primarily serve local neighborhood needs for convenience retail services and professional office establishments as well as high density multihousehold residential use gb zone general business this zoning district is intended for commercial areas that serve townwide and regional commercial needs for retail services and professional office establishments d zone downtown this zoning district is intended for the preservation of downtown commercial areas mmu zone metacom mixed use this zoning district is intended for designating key areas along the metacom avenue rt 136 corridor for focused development or redevelopment in dense mixeduse zones to help create a sense of place and order and encourage the expansion of business use areas while creating vibrant walkable neighborhoods well served with appropriately scaled retail services and other commercial development 3 industrial zoning districts industrial zoning districts shall be as follows m zone manufacturing this zone is intended for general industrial uses that accommodate a variety of manufacturing assembly storage of durable goods and related activities provided that they do not pose toxic explosive or environmental hazard in the town 4 open space zoning district the open space zoning district shall be as follows os zone open space this zone is intended for the preservation of open space in the town 5 waterfront zoning district the waterfront zoning district shall be as follows w zone waterfront this zone is intended for mixed use residential commercial and limited industrial use along the downtown waterfront with an emphasis on preservation economic development recreation and open space 6 educationalinstitutional zoning district the educationalinstitutional zoning district shall be as follows ei zone educational institutional this zone is intended for collegeuniversity facilities to be used in a planned manner while protecting surrounding cultural historic and environmental resources 65 historic preservation and conservation zoning district the historic preservation and conservation zoning district shall be as follows hpc zone the purpose of the hpc zone is to preserve and protect the existing uses of historic properties of importance to the town  and to allow them to be used in a planned manner and permit certain minimal additions to those existing uses  while protecting and preserving the cultural historic and environmental resources of the property and the town 7 special zones special zones shall be as follows historic district overlay zone this overlay zoning district is intended to preserve the heritage of the town by placing additional design standards for buildings or other structures and lots either within an historic district or designated as an individual historic district residential cluster overlay zone this overlay zoning district is intended to allow clustering of dwelling units while promoting the conservation of agricultural use open space or other resources of natural cultural or historic significance resource conservation and creative development overlay the intent of this overlay zoning district is to require the clustering of dwelling units so that they are located out of agricultural areas areas of cultural or historic significance  and sensitive natural areas which might otherwise be lost under conventional development limited commercial uses designed to serve the needs of the residents and reduce the need for automobile travel may also be permitted flood hazard overlay zone this overlay zoning district is intended to protect the floodplain areas in bristol by placing additional review construction and design standards on development in the floodplain urban rehab ldp overlay zone rehab land development project this zone is intended to encourage the rehabilitation and reuse of deteriorated underutilized and inefficient historic andor nonconforming structures of conservation concern to the town route 136 metacom avenue overlay zone this overlay zone is intended to provide for high quality development mitigation of traffic impacts protection of residential uses and preservation of scenic resources along metacom avenue by placing additional review criteria and design standards on development in this area official zoning map the official zoning map of the town shall consist of an official zoning map in the office of the town clerk entitled town of bristol rhode island official map of zoning districts dated  as amended and shall depict all zoning districts and overlay zoning districts the town of bristol rhode island official map of zoning districts shall constitute the official zoning map of the town and is hereby adopted and made part of this chapter zone boundaries where uncertainty exists as to the boundaries of the zoning districts as shown on the official zoning map the following rules shall apply 1 zone boundaries are generally intended to coincide with lot lines  2 land hereafter created by the filling or change of level of water bodies shall assume that zone of adjacent land compliance with chapter a conformance with permitted uses no building or structure shall be erected reconstructed enlarged or moved for any use other than that which is permitted in the zone in which such building structure or land is located nor shall any building structure or land be used for any use other than is permitted in the zone in which it is located b dimensional conformance no new lot shall be created nor shall an existing lot be reduced or diminished except in conformance with the dimensional requirements of this chapter nor shall the number of dwelling units or occupancy thereon be increased in any manner except in conformance with the dimensional requirements of this chapter interpretation it shall be the duty of the zoning enforcement officer to interpret and apply the provisions of this chapter and the official zoning map such interpretation and application shall be subject to appeal to the zoning board according to the provisions of article xi of this chapter secs 2882830  reserved article ii  administration footnotes  2  cross reference administration ch 2 division 1  generally maintenance of chapter the town clerk shall be the custodian of this chapter and zoning maps created thereunder the director of community development shall be responsible for maintenance and update of the text and zoning map comprising this chapter changes which impact the zoning map shall be depicted on the map within 90 days of such authorized changes the director with the planning board shall be responsible for review of this chapter annually and whenever changes are made to the comprehensive plan of the town to identify any changes necessary and forward these changes to the town council publication and availability of chapter a printed copies of this chapter and maps shall be available to the general public town clerk and shall be revised to include all amendments a reasonable charge may be made for copies to reflect printing and distribution costs b upon publication of this chapter and maps and any amendments thereto the town clerk shall send a copy without charge to the associate director of the division of planning of the department of administration of the state and to the state law library vested rights a any application for development under this chapter including an application for a building permit special use permit variance planned development or land development project shall be deemed substantially complete when all required documents for the initial application including plans together with required fees are received by the official designated herein to receive such applications required documents shall include only those documents specified either by this chapter or by rules adopted and published by the permitting authority prior to the time the application is filed b any application for development under this chapter that is substantially complete prior to the enactment or amendment of this chapter shall be reviewed according to the regulations applicable in the chapter in force at the time the application was submitted if such application is approved the applicant must begin construction or exercise the right granted in the application if no construction is involved not more than one year after the date of such approval all construction must be completed not more than two years after the date of such approval unless specifically set forth to the contrary in the original approval secs 28342850  reserved division 2  amendment of zoning provisions procedure the director of community development shall be the officer to receive a proposal for adoption amendment or repeal of the provisions of this chapter or the zoning maps at the request of the director or the persons presenting the proposal a preapplication meeting may be held to discuss the proposed amendment immediately upon receipt of such proposal the director shall refer such proposal to the town council and the planning board for study and recommendation 1 planning board review the planning board shall seek the advice of the community development department and shall report to the town council within 45 days after receipt of the proposal giving its findings and recommendations in its findings and recommendations to the town council the planning board shall a include a statement on the general consistency of the proposal with towns comprehensive plan including the goals and policies statements the implementation program and all other applicable elements of the comprehensive plan  and b include a demonstration of recognition and consideration of each of the applicable purposes of zoning as presented in section 282 where a proposal for adoption amendment or repeal of the provisions of this chapter or the zoning map is made by the planning board then the requirements for study by the planning board may be waived provided that the proposal by the board includes its findings and recommendations as prescribed above 2 town council hearing the town council shall hold a public hearing within 65 days of receipt of proposal giving proper notice as prescribed in section 2852 the town council shall render a decision within 45 days after the date of completion of the public hearing the town council may not make any decisions that are inconsistent with the findings of the planning board unless the council makes their own findings of facts present in the record that the findings of the planning board are in clear error or clearly exceed their authority the provisions of this subsection pertaining to deadlines shall not be construed to apply to any extension consented to by the applicant notice and hearing requirements a no provision of this chapter shall be adopted repealed or amended until after a public hearing has been held upon the question before the town council the town council shall first give notice of such public hearing by publication of notice in a newspaper of general circulation within the town at least once each week for three consecutive weeks prior to the date of such hearing which may include the week in which the hearing is to be held at which hearing opportunity shall be given to all persons interested to be heard upon the matter of the proposed ordinance written notice which may be a copy of such newspaper notice shall be mailed to the associate director of the division of planning of the state department of administration and where applicable to the parties specified in subsections b c d and e of this section at least two weeks prior to the hearing such newspaper notice shall be published as a display advertisement using a type size at least as large as the normal type size used by the newspaper in its news articles and shall 1 specify the place of the hearing and the date and time of its commencement  2 indicate the provisions for adoption amendment or repeal of this chapter that is under consideration  3 contain a statement of the proposed amendments to this chapter that may be printed once in its entirety or summarize or describe the matter under consideration  4 advise those interested where and when a copy of the matter under consideration may be obtained or examined and copied  and 5 state that the proposal shown thereon may be altered or amended prior to the close of the public hearing without further advertising as a result of further study or because of the views expressed at the public hearing any such alteration or amendment must be presented for comment in the course of the hearing b where a proposed general amendment to the existing provisions of this chapter includes changes in an existing zoning map public notice shall be given as required by subsection a of this section c where a proposed amendment to an existing provision of this chapter includes a specific change in a zoning district map but does not affect districts generally public notice shall be given as required in subsection a of this section with the additional requirements that 1 notice shall include a map showing the existing and proposed boundaries zoning district boundaries and existing streets and roads and their names and town boundaries where appropriate  and 2 written notice of the date time and place of the public hearing and the nature and purpose thereof shall be sent by certified mail to all owners of real property whose property is located within 200 feet of the perimeter of the area proposed for change whether within the town of bristol or within an adjacent town warren in which the property is located d notice of a public hearing shall be sent by first class mail to the town council of any town to which one or more of the following pertain 1 which is located within 200 feet of the boundary of the area proposed for change  or 2 where there is a public or quasipublic water source or private water source that is used or is suitable for use as a public water source within 2000 feet of any real property that is the subject of a proposed zoning change regardless of municipal boundaries e notice of a public hearing shall be sent to the governing body of any state or municipal water department agency special water district or private water company that has riparian rights to a surface water resource andor surface watershed that is used or is suitable for use as a public water source and that is within 2000 feet of any real property which is the subject of a proposed zoning change provided however that the governing body of any state or municipal water company has filed with the director in the town a map survey which shall be kept as a public record showing areas of surface water resources andor watersheds and parcels of land within 2000 feet thereof f no defect in the form of any notice under this section shall render an ordinance or amendment invalid unless such defect is found to be intentional or misleading g costs of any notice required under this section shall be borne by the applicant conditional zoning amendments a in granting an amendment to this chapter notwithstanding the provisions of rigl  452337 the town council may limit the change to one or more of the permitted uses in the zone to which the subject land is rezoned and impose such limitations conditions and restrictions including without limitation 1 requiring the petitioner to obtain a permit or approval from any and all federal state or local governmental agencies or instrumentalities having jurisdiction over the land and use which are the subject of the zoning change  2 those relating to the effectiveness or continued effectiveness of the zoning change  andor 3 those relating to the use of the land as it deems necessary b the director of community development shall cause the limitations and conditions so imposed to be clearly noted on the zoning map and recorded in the land evidence records  provided however in the case of a conditional zone change the limitations restrictions and conditions shall not be noted on the zoning map until the zone change has become effective c if the permitted use for which the land has been rezoned is abandoned or if the land is not used for the requested purpose for a period of two years or more after the zone change becomes effective the town council may after notice and a public hearing as herein before set forth change the land back to its original zoning use before the petition was filed appeal of enactment of or amendment to chapter an appeal of the enactment of or an amendment to this chapter may be taken to the superior court for providence and bristol counties by filing a complaint within 30 days after such enactment or amendment has become effective the complaint shall set forth with specificity the area in which the enactment or amendment does not conform with the comprehensive plan andor the manner in which it constitutes a taking of private property without just compensation such appeal may be taken by an aggrieved party or by any legal resident or landowner of the town or by any association of residents or landowners of the town this appeal shall not stay the enforcement of this chapter as enacted or amended but the court may in its discretion grant a stay on appropriate terms which may include the filing of a bond and make such other orders as it deems necessary for an equitable disposition of the appeal secs 28552880  reserved article iii  permitted uses compliance with regulations the regulations set forth in this article shall be minimum regulations and shall apply to each class or kind of structure or land use regulations a generally the following permitted use table is designed to regulate land uses in the various zoning districts in town 1 permitted uses are denoted with a y for yes  2 uses not permitted are denoted with an n for no  and 3 uses permitted only upon approval of the zoning board are denoted with an s for a special use permit uses permitted by special use permit for which there are andor other understory growth to mitigate the impact of the manufacturing development on the residential district b the manufacturer or developer is required to discuss appropriate buffers with the director of community development c the residential side of the buffer shall be defined with a split rail fence picket fence or stone wall chain link fences shall not meet the requirements of fencing
